Many of these films will be shown on two different dates, and so please feel free to post comments below (regarding the films you're most interested in attending or perhaps  dates where you might be interested) and perhaps we can try to schedule some alternate dates for Meetup groups to check out various films as well as the Opening Night Gala on July 9.

For more information, please visit Silk Screen at http://www.silkscreenfestival.org

For more information about the PhAb Now! abstract photography exhibit in the Filmmakers Galleries during June 26 - September 4, 2015, please visit http://filmmakers.pfpca.org/exhibitions/phab-now

For a listing of upcoming films at the Harris Theater, Melwood Screening Room, and Regent Square Theater (which are all operated by Pittsburgh Filmmakers), please visit http://cinema.pfpca.org/

Stay tuned for updates!

results.description:
Join us for the PDMA Pittsburgh Summer Social at a little known but beautiful historic landmark in Pittsburgh - The Priory.

We will start of the evening with a stimulating talk by renowned strategist and innovation consultant Mark McClusky. He will enlighten us with his experience in “Killing the Sacred Cow - when and how to terminate projects, product lines or even businesses”. 

We will continue the evening in the unique ambiance of The Priory’s patio area with drinks and light fare giving you ample opportunity for great conversations and networking.  We encourage you to approach the PDMA Board Members who will be present to share your thoughts on past Chapter performance and your ideas and expectations for the chapter’s future.

The history of The Priory began in 1848 with the foundation of St. Mary’s Parish by German, Austrian and Swiss immigrants in the neighborhood that is now known as “Deutschtown”.  In 1850 the parishioners began building their own church and in 1888 the priory for Benedictine monks was established.  Today The Priory is a unique boutique hotel and the church is Pittsburgh’s Grand Hall at The Priory.

The Priory offers discounted room rates to visiting participants who wish to spend the night. Please contact The Priory directly and mention your attendance at the PDMA event to take advantage of the discounted rates ($165 King; $145 Queen). 

About the Speaker


Mark McClusky founded Newry Corp in 1987 to help executives with the challenges of technology-based growth.

He has nearly 30 years of experience in designing strategies to commercialize new products and technologies, developing frameworks to evaluate business development projects, and evaluating operations strategies for both existing and emerging technologies. 

Before founding Newry, Mr. McClusky was with New York Consulting Partners and Vice President of Sales and Marketing for Nanofilm.  Prior to that, he was Field Marketing Manager for Honeywell Information Systems, where he was twice the national sales leader.

Mark has established and maintained advisory relationships with some of the world's leading innovators on technology and commercial strategy and has lectured and facilitated numerous forums on innovation.

Schedule of Events  

4:30 - 5:00 p.m.   Doors Open and Networking 

5:00 - 5:30 p.m.     Presentation

5:30 - 7:00 p.m.     Socializing and Networking

Registration Fees

Non-members  $15                                      $20  

Students             $15                                      $20

results.description:
Microservices - Beyond the Hype

Presented by Eric Kepes

Microservices are all the rage these days. Everyone is trying to sell their vision of SOA as "microservices". You know it has reached the mainstream, because the backlash has started, too.

When you boil it down, Microservices trade business domain complexity for infrastructure complexity. If you have a lot of business domains, this can help keep your software from turning into a big ball of mud. If you don't, it's just building complexity for complexity's sake.

In this talk, we will look at why and when you would want to build microservices, how you would do so, and what to avoid. We won't fixate on the size of services, but on how to split things apart. After this talk, you should know if you should consider using microservices.

-- Meeting Sponsor--

This meeting is sponsored by S2scout.

S2scout is comprised of seasoned recruiters, a.k.a. “Scouts”, who are dedicated to helping clients AND candidates find the right talent or opportunity without wasting anyone's time.  

Our dedication to providing clients AND candidates with fresh talent or unique opportunities is in the “S2scout” name. “S2” is the military term for intelligence. “Scout”, by definition, is a person sent out ahead of a main force to gather information about the target's position, strength and movements.

Our recruiters don’t sit and wait for candidates to come to them, our Scouts are in front of the search utilizing tactics that are…well…CLASSIFIED.

S2scout is a Pittsburgh based Service-Disabled Veteran-Owned Small Business (SDVOSB) providing specialized staffing services to small, medium and large organizations across several industries.
results.name: Microservices - Beyond the Hype

Join us on Tuesdays for American Mah Jong! Folks begin arriving around 5PM, and play begins table by table as soon as we have three or four players plus a set.  (We usually have 3-5 tables.)  By 6:15 or so, most players have arrived. We rotate among the tables... at the end of each game, East walks around to see if another table is close to the end of their game, so that two players can swap places.   At the other end of the evening... play must end by 9PM when Panera closes.  Tables begin wrapping up play any time after 8:15 or so.


If you have never played, or if you have not played for a very long time, we highly recommend that you take a Mah Jong 101 beginner class before playing with us - beginner classes are offered every few months.  Mah jong is a wonderful game, but it's hard to learn by just watching others play!


Please order your 2015 card from the National Mah Jongg League, here: http://www.nationalmahjonggleague.org/ Amazon.com also carries the cards. Note that you want the NMJL card, and no other! (There are some colorful alternatives out there.. but we play NMJL card and rules.)

Experienced players -- please bring your cards and please bring a set if you have one.

Please do not bring any outside food or beverages into Panera! Instead, please plan to buy *something* from Panera, even if it's just a beverage or a cookie, to support their willingness to host us.

results.description:
Coach Anne-Marie Alderson will conduct a free running clinic prior to our standard 3-event workout (events to be announced).  She'll also tell us about her upcoming 6-week group training program which begins on either July 15th or 16th and is open to all ability levels.  (Perfect if you want to prepare for a 5k later this summer!)

It's cool that our weekly participants bring such a breath of knowledge and athletic backgrounds- from folks new to exercise, to rowers, runners, and even a pro football player.  I look forward to building our "melting pot" of knowledge with the experience that Anne-Marie brings as an experienced cyclist and triathlete.  It'll also be fun to compete along-side her in our three events!

Note: This evening will end later than normal (approx 8:00-8:10 p.m.) due to the 30-minute running clinic.

About Coach Anne-Marie

Coach Anne-Marie is an ITCA-certified triathlon coach who has competed in over 30 triathlons, ranging from sprint to Ironman distance.  In addition to triathlon, she's run in numerous races of all distances from 5k to marathon, and also races as a Category 3 cyclist in road cycling.  She provides associate coaching services to Pittsburgh-based Steel City Endurance.

In 2014, she decided to try something different and competed as part of a 4-woman relay team in Race Across America, a bicycle race covering 3,000+ miles from Oceanside, CA to Annapolis, MD.  Team PHenomenal Hope raced in honor of patients living with Pulmonary Hypertension and with the goal of raising disease awareness and research funds to find a cure.  Crossing the country by bike in 7 days, 7 hours, and 15 minutes was amazing experience and provided a new perspective on “endurance sports”!

results.description:
How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other? 


Imagine meeting new people in an environment where people felt comfortable to be themselves. That's what we've created!

It's a refreshing change from the typical networking or sports bar conversation.

We play three communication games that will challenge you to consider questions like 'What are your relationships like?' 'What does Orgasm mean to you?' and 'What's one secret desire you have?'

Questions like these encourage vulnerability. And, what happens when you get vulnerable? It creates intimacy... which is what we're all searching for!

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to say what's real.

At OneTaste we teach a wellness practice known as Orgasmic Meditation (OM for short.) The games we play at TurnON are designed to create the visceral sensation of OM, without having to actually do the practice (or remove any clothing!) - sort of like having the feeling of an incredible dessert without having consumed any of the calories.

You can play and participate at whatever level feels comfortable to you!

It's a friendly invitation to play and push your edges in a way that feels good. This allows you to stretch yourself and inspires self-discovery!

We start on time so please arrive fifteen minutes early.

COST TO ATTEND IS $10.

For questions feel free to contact Stephen Horvath at[masked]-8411.

Any non member is subject to removal from this website, if they RSVP for an event and they do not attend.

If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

results.description:
Open Discussion Nights are donation based events SparkleDragon and I (Rebekah Gamble, Holistic Practitioner) are bringing to the community once or twice a month in the interest of building community and public education. For the time that the event runs, I will be available to discuss a pre-chosen topic with you one on one and with whomever is in the group that evening.

This month we're repeating one we had last month because it was so much fun! These events are very informal and consist of participants sitting together, having the space to share experiences and ask questions, and of course drinking tea, graciously provided by the Emporium.

This event is not a formal presentation, but I will be bringing many of my tools and work from the Andes to the event. You can pet a baby llama, see an alter piece, hold tools and play a drum made by shamans in the jungle, take a look at photos, listen to music from an ayahuasca ceremony, hold the leaves from a sacred plant and touch the feathers of the condor. I will also be talking about the things I've learned in the temples and sacred sites in Peru and Bolivia, including Coricancha, Saqsayhuaman, Machu Pichu, Ollantaytambo, Wiracocha, Tiahuanaco, Puma Punko, the Sacred Valley and the valley of Tinanjani. I will also be sharing my personal experiences with the healing of the Andean teachings, Coca leaf work, and Wachuma.

I met my second teacher in the Andean tradition for this work and he has authorized me to speak to you on these topics. His name is Jhaimy and you can contact him here if you wish to verify this information: https://www.facebook.com/jhaimy.alvarezacosta?fref=ts

I will share with you everything I can (because I love you!). My other qualifications in medicine ways don't matter, but if you're curious ask and I'll answer. You can also check out my website for more info on me an what I do: http://rebekahgambleholisticpractitioner.com/

This event is being offered without charge in the interest of building a healthy community, but if you'd like to support my work and the shop, donations of $5-$10 are happily accepted and are split between the two hosts. There is no end time because we could talk for hours. The event will end when we're bored or tired, it gets very late, or it simply seems done. Feel free to come in or leave at any time during the event, we won't think any less of you. :-)

Looking forward to seeing you there!
results.name: Open Discussion: My Trip to Peru and Bolivia

results.description:
We're excited to have Michelle Gilboy share with us her expert advice on conflict resolution and collaboration.

When business people and developers work together daily throughout their project, great things can happen…and sometimes things can get messy. Collaboration is tricky but worth it. The diversity of ideas and experiences while collaborating can sometimes cause friction or conflict. During the session you will understand the benefits of conflict, gain insights into why conflict is so darn tricky and learn to arm yourself with a few tools to for the next time you find yourself in a sticky spot.

This session is appropriate for all humans that have face to face interactions. 

About Michelle:
Michelle is a software development professional with 18 years of diverse process, project and leadership experiences. Michelle is mad for Lean and a geek for Agile. Her experience includes roles as Software Developer & QA, Agile Coach, Scrum Master, Project Manager, Product Owner and Software Development Manager.
Michelle is a self-proclaimed change agent and challenger of status quo. Her favorite things are to teach, learn and attack problems. Working for Aesynt for almost 14 years, she’s had the great pleasure of being part of Aesynt’s continual evolution from traditional software development to being Agile. Her accreditations include CSM, CSPO and PMP. In her spare time Michelle teaches group fitness classes including Zumba and Kettlebell.
results.name: Collaboration is tricky...but worth it

results.description:
We are organizing a group of product managers and user experience people who want to meet up on a monthly basis.  This will be our second meeting and a chance to influence the goals and structure of this group.  Feel free to share this event with like minded peers.


Our goal for the group will be primarily to enable peers to network and learn from each other.  We are planning on having a panel of speakers for the August event.  Please stop by and see Eric if you are interested in speaking in the future or have a topic you would like to see discussed.

We are also looking for sponsors, who can help cover costs (food, drinks, maybe speaker costs) in exchange for access to the group through some advertising.  Ideally, we would look for sponsors who can add value to the lives of product managers/user experience folks or who are looking to hire those types of people.   Reach out to Eric if you know of sponsors who would be interested.

We will have limited room so please grab a free ticket if you are planning on attending.  And please cancel if you cannot make it.  You can sign up here or via eventbrite at https://www.eventbrite.com/e/july-15th-product-engagement-meetup-tickets-17673372533?utm_campaign=new_event_email&utm_medium=email&utm_source=eb_email&utm_term=eventurl_text

Current Sponsor List:

Pendo.io -  Pendo is a data driven platform for product engagement that enables companies to improve on boarding, understand product usage and help retain customers. Pendo combines enterprise guidance and user insights to enable product teams to understand and influence their customer’s experience. Pendo installs in minutes with no coding required.

So visit pendo.io and maybe sign up for a demo.
results.name: July Product Engagement Meetup

results.description:
See this event information at: http://www.gamemasterspgh.com/?tribe_events=deadlands-the-weird-west&eventDate=2015-03-11

This game is looking for players. "Deadlands: The Weird West" is a setting
where steam-powered jetpacks and zeppelins share space with cowboys,
sharp-eyed prospectors, and smoky desert saloons while inhuman
abominations and unsettling mysteries hide in every shadow.
 1876. The American Civil War has been going for 17 years with
no end in sight, and now being fought with steam-powered
tanks, flying machines, and man-portable Gatling rifles. The Quake of
 smashed California into a labyrinth of shattered plateaus and
treacherous rapids known as the "Great Maze", and the Sioux Nations
have reclaimed the Dakotas.
 Rumors have spread across the nation that the West is beset by
everything from giant, man-eating bats to the walking dead, and while
people in more civilized parts of the continent think  all
bunk,  mostly because the Union and Confederate governments
have done their best to hide the facts from them: truth is, magic and
monsters are very, very real, and there are larger forces behind their
sudden return.
 Anyone is free to join, regardless of prior experience: just walk in
and ask. I can be contacted through my e-mail or at[masked] (aim
for 11:30 AM to 5:30 PM) and am happy to help with character creation,
take suggestions on what mood or tone you would like to see in the
game, and answer questions.
results.name: Deadlands - The Weird West

results.description:
Regular season weekly Wednesday Start and Stop Clinic and organized street skates in Shadyside.

 

"FREE" Lessons start at 6:30 pm & the street skates start at 7:00 pm. If you need loaner skates, helmet, wrist guards for lessons please call [masked]) at least 2 days in advance or email at: [masked]

Two (2) street skates available:

Beginners Skate (7:15pm) is for those new to skating and having learned some of the basic skating and braking skills. Lasts about 45 minutes. Skate is on fairly level back streets of Shadyside with minimal traffic. This is a patrolled skate.

Advanced Beginners Skate (7:00pm) for those who can brake and skate with confidence and are ready to improve their skills. Ability to skate small hills and some street traffic. Skate lasts from about 1 to 1  1/2 hours. Skate route is generally from Shadyside to Oakland, Pitt, CMU and surrounding areas. This is a patrolled skate.

Helmets and wrist guards required as a minimum on all skates.

Occasional post skate tailgate gathering or walk to local eateries after the skate.

Note: All skates are weather permitting. If the streets are dry we should be skating!

Lessons are conducted by the National Skate Patrol.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet on a paved school yard, off street, fenced school yard area between Filbert and Ivy Streets along Ellsworth Ave. in Shadyside.
results.name: TRIC / NSP - Wednesday Beginners Skates & FREE Skate Lessons

results.description:
Meet, Greet, Drink, and Collaborate.

Wednesday, July 15, 7-9:30p

With Mobile Ad Networks, Wearables, and The Internet of Things, there is a lot going on for apps.

This Meetup will be a good opportunity to make an introduction, learn what others are working on, and ask for help with your projects.

This is for those who are new to apps, are working on an app,
or who have created an app for themselves or a client. 

The Agenda:

7:00 - 7:30 arrive: mix, have-a-drink, and mingle;
7:30 - 8:00 introductions around the room: this is the time to mention what you're working on or interests in apps;
8:00 - 8:30 now that everyone has introduced themselves: network with those with common interests;
8:30 - 9:00 we pass the mike so everyone can ask for help with a project or offer their services;
9:00 - don't hesitate to chat with those you can help or who can help you.

It should be a productive and fun time.

I hope to see you soon.

Gene

results.description:
Hey guys!  

We're Back!  It's been a few weeks since we've had a gig so this feels good!  Some of us are rusty (cough cough!) and could really use a hardcore environment of still life to inspire some creativity.  Entire the Carnegie Museums...

Time to resurrect a beloved tradition, folks!  

Both the Art and Natural History Museums close at 8pm on Thursdays and offer a reduced $10 admission after 3pm.    We'll meet in the lobby of the Art Museum in front of the gift shop at 5:30pm and stay there for about 15 minutes.   

For those of you who may be new to this (and possibly late) --- We normally scatter for the first hour to hour and half (usually in the Natural History side, but open it up ya'll!), then meet up at a specified location to show/discuss our work, and continue sketching together.

If you're coming late, call or text me at[masked] so you'll be able to find us.

Come, relax, unwind, and enjoy homemade Mediterrean food with fellow women rideshare drivers! Dips, fallael, salads, desserts, drinks, music, and activities will be provided, in a laid back setting. While there, learn about to how make Lyft work for you, and get your questions answered. We will also cover the ins and outs of rideshares and provide tips and tools to help women succeed. This is a weekly event. Each week we'll have free food, drinks, music, and games. We'll also have free themed nights, like a mani-pedi night, movie nights, sushi and wine nights, go-carts, etc., all of which is totally FREE!!! These are low-key, laid back events, meant to provide a chance for women in the rideshare community to get together and hangout.

RSVP to reserve your spot. For women only. Address will be given upon confirmation of RSVP.

results.description:
We will be hosting a panel discussion on the strategies available to hardware startups with regards to securing IP, open sourcing, and licensing options.

This one will be held at AlphaLab Gear. As always, we will have food and beverages.

Panelists (more to follow)

Kathleen Kuznicki


Kathleen is a Patent Attorney registered with the United States Patent and Trademark Office. She works with individuals or businesses, including start-up businesses, to protect some of their most valuable assets, their intellectual property.  Kathleen earned her Juris Doctor degree from the Duquesne University School of Law. She has a Bachelor of Science degree in Biology from the Pennsylvania State University, a Doctor of Philosophy degree in Microbiology-Medicine from the University of Missouri-Columbia, and 5 years post-doctoral research experience in the Department of Neurobiology at the University of Pittsburgh. Though her background is based in Biology, Kathleen works on patent applications in a number of technical fields including medical devices, metallurgical compositions, sporting equipment, software, and manufactured articles.

Malcolm Handelsman

Malcolm has 30+ years of financial and operations experience in public and private companies. He obtained his MBA from the University of Pittsburgh and worked for National Intergroup as an Auditor and at Mellon Bank in their Real Estate Finance Department. During this time he also obtained his CPA certification. In 2010, he was recruited by Morgan Stanley to become a Financial Advisor but realized his heart was in the business and entrepreneurial world. In the fall of 2011 he started Do It Right, helping entrepreneurs and early stage companies to raise money and grow their businesses. Over the last two years, Malcolm has worked with several start-up companies, primarily technology and consumer product companies, helping them realize their dream. His key strengths include financial management, strategic planning, marketing, revenue and business modeling, and business development.

Tim Fletcher

Tim has over 25 years of experience as an industrial designer in corporate, consulting and academic environments. He is experienced in design within multiple markets, including infant products, exercise equipment/accessories, consumer/commercial electronics and housewares. He has been an expert witness involved in design patent and trade dress law. Tim will discuss the sometimes little understood and often overlooked areas of Intellectual Property protection that have increased in value since the Apple v. Samsung cases.

Dick Zhang

Identified Technologies’ CEO Dick leads the rapidly growing company’s mission to deliver big insights for big jobs. Identified Technologies uses self-piloting drones to automatically, safely, and scalably provide continuous site monitoring to blue chip construction and energy companies around the world. Dick’s experience includes corporate strategy at Goldman Sachs and project management at Bristol-Myers Squibb. A technologist as well as entrepreneur, Dick is an alumnus of the University of Pennsylvania with training in Mechanical Engineering and several U.S. patents. Dick is a Pittsburgh Business Times Fast Tracker, Point Park University guest lecturer, and has been featured with Identified Technologies by TechCrunch, CNN, INC, and NBC.


Craig Waller

Craig is an Intellectual Property Attorney employing business-minded approaches to go beyond ordinary answers for creative resolution of complex IP issues. Adept at proactively identifying key areas for efficiency improvements, minimizing risk and/or effectuating monetization to achieve organizational objectives. Trusted strategic thought-leader as an IP executive management advisor, facilitating internal Intellectual Asset management strategies and processes to reduce waste while enhancing valuation. Consistent consensus builder providing goal-oriented leadership and vision as nationally recognized Board Chair with tech focused organization MIT Enterprise Forum Pittsburgh.
results.name: Intellectual Property Panel Discussion

results.description:
Cross posting from another meetup. Not exactly volleyball, but it's good practice.


So what's Spikeball!? Well, it's a new game sweeping across college campuses, beaches, and yards everywhere. Many describe it as a cross between volleyball and four square. Here's the skinny: Using just a ball and net/trampoline, the object is to win points where you or your teammate have up to 3 hits before you spike the ball into net, while not letting the ball touch the ground. Simple! However you describe it, it's 2-on-2 fast-paced fun. We can get into the specific rules for the beginners and curious alike and hopefully get some games going.

We'll setup shop in the field by the turnaround on Overlook Drive in Schenley Park, just passed the tennis courts.
results.name: Intro to Spikeball

results.description:
Dear Six Sensory Members


In our next meet up we will have another fun and interactive session about feeding your spirit.  Although we all share the same eternal breath of life, it manifests differently in each of us. Your spirit has its own presence, a unique vibration that’s totally distinct from your personality. The best way to connect with your own spirit is to start recognizing what makes you come alive.

We will explore what your unique spirit is really like. How would you describe the eternal, fiery life force call you?

Next we will begin to notice what feeds your spirit. That is, what experiences, activities, and energies give you strength and fortify and nourish you at the core, leaving you feeling satisfied, content with life, and comfortable in your own skin? What delights and surprises you, draws you into life, helping you embrace it head on; and brings you to peace with yourself?

This meet-up promises to be a fun and enlightening experience. Hope to see you there!

Love and Blessings,

Joe
results.name: Pittsburgh Six Sensory Meet Up

results.description:
Proficiency Level
Intermediate

To combat both the inherent and user-induced weaknesses of text-based passwords, administrators and organizations typically institute a series of rules – a password policy – to which users must adhere when choosing a password. While a properly-written password policy might provide an organization with increased security, it is unclear just what such a well-written policy would be, or even how to determine whether a given policy is effective. Although it is easy to calculate the theoretical password space that corresponds to a particular password policy, it is difficult to determine the practical password space. Users may, for example, react to a policy rule requiring them to include numbers in passwords by overwhelmingly picking the same number, or by always using the number in the same location in their passwords. In addition, some password policies, while resulting in stronger passwords, may make those passwords difficult to remember or type. This may cause users to forget their passwords or to engage in a variety of behaviors that might compromise the security of passwords. We seek to advance understanding of the factors that make following password policies difficult, collect empirical data on password strength and memorability under various password policies, and propose password policy guidelines to simultaneously maximize security and usability of passwords. To that end, our research group has conducted a series of online studies in which we asked tens of thousands of people to create passwords that comply with specific password policies. We developed an efficient method for calculating how effectively several password-guessing algorithms guess passwords and used it to analyze leaked password sets, passwords created for our studies, and the single-sign-on passwords used by over 25,000 faculty, staff, and students at our university. We investigated a variety of password policies, including those with requirements on length and character classes, as well as exclusion of blacklisted words. We also investigated system-assigned passphrases and the impact of various password meter designs on password security and usability. In this talk I will describe our password research study methodology and highlight some of our most interesting findings. Our password research papers are available at http://cups.cs.cmu.edu/passwords.html

Lorrie Faith Cranor is a Professor of Computer Science and of Engineering and Public Policy at Carnegie Mellon University where she is director of the CyLab Usable Privacy and Security Laboratory (CUPS) and co-director of the MSIT-Privacy Engineering masters program. She is also a co-founder of Wombat Security Technologies, Inc. She has authored over 150 research papers on online privacy, usable security, and other topics. She has played a key role in building the usable privacy and security research community, having co-edited the seminal book Security and Usability (O'Reilly 2005) and founded the Symposium On Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS). She has served on a number of boards, including the Electronic Frontier Foundation Board of Directors, and on the editorial boards of several journals. In 2003 she was named one of the top 100 innovators 35 or younger by Technology Review magazine and in 2014 she was named an ACM Fellow for her contributions to usable privacy and security research and education. She was previously a researcher at AT&T-Labs Research and taught in the Stern School of Business at New York University. In[masked] she spent her sabbatical year as a fellow in the Frank-Ratchye STUDIO for Creative Inquiry at Carnegie Mellon University where she worked on fiber arts projects that combined her interests in privacy and security, quilting, computers, and technology. She practices yoga, plays soccer, and runs after her three children.
results.name: July Presentation - The continuing quest for secure and usable passwords

results.description:
Join us for a performance of the musical "Damn Yankees" on Thursday, July 16 at 7:30 pm (or other performance dates shown below) at the Beaux Arts Ballroom in the Twentieth Century Club in Oakland.


DAMN YANKEES REVIEW: Julia Fox as the devilish Applegate "blew the lid off the joint" with some Mozartian coloratura fun and the whole cast gets high marks from The Pittsburgh Stage - Online Magazine.


http://pghstage.com/drupal_old/node/601

Check out more great reviews from the Post Gazette, Trib, and City Paper http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/music/2015/07/16/Review-Switch-hitting-Damn-Yankees-scores/stories/201507160065

http://triblive.com/aande/theaterarts/8661506-74/opera-theater-yankees#axzz3fzldNuLE


http://www.pghcitypaper.com/Blogh/archives/2015/07/15/a-review-of-damn-yankees-at-opera-theater-summerfest


About this production
America's favorite pastime meets the Broadway stage in "Damn Yankees", Adler and Ross' 1955 musical hit. Washington Senators fan Joe Boyd wishes his team had a great hitter, and, in a Faustian deal with the devil (and the devil's assistant, Lola), becomes the team's savior—until he has second thoughts and tries to return to his previous life. The action is propelled by great songs such as "You Gotta Have Heart" and "Whatever Lola Wants." Think you already know Damn Yankees? Think again, because SummerFest puts a new spin on the ball in a role-reversed version of this classic favorite. 

Arrive early for each performance for tailgate-style food options (hotdogs for $3 and hamburgers for $5, served with a side of homemade potato chips!) available for purchase starting one hour before curtain time - no reservations necessary!


For more details on this production, please visit
http://otsummerfest.org/events/damn-yankees


Other Performance Dates:
• Saturday 11 July at 7:30 pm
• Sunday 12 July at 2:00 pm
• Friday 17 July at 7:30 pm
• Saturday 25 July at 2:00 pm
• Saturday 01 August at 2:00 pm


Pre-Curtain Talks
Join us one hour before curtain time for an informal and informative talk with members of the Damn Yankees creative team. Free for all ticket holders—no reservations required.
• Sunday 12 July at 1:00 pm
• Thursday 16 July at 6:30 pm
• Friday 17 July at 6:30 pm
• Saturday 25 July at 1:00 pm
• Saturday 01 August at 1:00 pm


Opening Night Party (July 11): Mingle with the cast and crew at a private party with drinks, light bites, and cabaret performances, immediately following the opening night performance on Saturday, July 11. The Opening Night ticket is $35 which also includes one drink and light bites (cash bar also available)


Ticket Discounts:
If you are new to Opera Theater, you can receive up to three tickets at 33% off by calling the box office at[masked] or at the door. Students with ID can get rush tickets 50% off at door.
Tickets start at $25, and there are a number of money saving subscription options:
http://otsummerfest.org/events/get-tickets


Check out the "Damn Yankees" Cast singing the national anthem at the Pirates game on July 7, 2015


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8pmue4fzu1A

More on Opera Theater SummerFest:
SummerFest 2015 is four weeks of opera sung in English, an international recital series, a children's opera, and more! Enjoy the world premiere of our newly-commissioned A New Kind of Fallout, two versions of Mozart's The Marriage of Figaro, Richard Strauss' enchanting Capriccio, and Damn Yankees, the all-American musical. Performances take place at the historic Twentieth Century Club in Oakland from July 10 – August 2. http://otsummerfest.org/events/calendar


Check out these great articles about the Opera Theater SummerFest and the various shows during July 10 – August 2 http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/music/2015/07/09/Opera-Theater-s-SummerFest-offers-unusual-productions-to-attract-new-audiences/stories/201507090084

http://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/opera-theaters-summerfest-features-rachel-carson-inspired-work/Content?oid=1838370

http://triblive.com/aande/music/8710170-74/figaro-mozart-production#axzz3fpdxwWpy

http://triblive.com/aande/theaterarts/8653726-74/opera-ryan-fallout#axzz3fzldNuLE

We've also added a Discussion Board forum for those that may wish to suggest some shows where perhaps some smaller groups of people could get together depending on their schedules. Please visit http://www.meetup.com/Art-lovers/messages/boards/thread/49092583

For more information about the beautiful, historic Twentieth Century Club, please visit http://www.thetwentiethcenturyclub.com/index.html

Directions/Parking/Dining:
There is some street parking but most parking across the street at Soldiers and Sailors. Detailed directions and dining options: http://otsummerfest.org/events/plan-your-visit

results.description:
Get Heard! Get Noticed! Get Leads! (TM)

Hosted by: Suzi Neft from Suzi Neft Promotes and Edie Coates from Ace In the Hole Entertainment.

This is an informal networking event, open to any business woman who would like to increase her business contacts or clients in the Monroeville area.

Things to bring:

- 10-20 business cards or marketing material

- cash for your lunch check

- $5 meeting fee (non members only)


AGENDA

1:00 pm - attendees arrive, reviews menu, gives the server their drink order, and open networking: everyone stands up to introduce oneself to others and pass their business card

1:15 pm - server takes lunch order and the sign in sheet is passed around

1:30 pm - 60 sec. commercials begin

2:00 pm - each person gives a testimony or referral for someone attending the lunch

2:15 pm - Premier member does a 5 min. company presentation

2:20 pm - WSBA announcements from Debi/Susan

2:30 pm - lunch has ended. Open networking is welcomed.

Be prepared to do a 60 second commercial about yourself. Please RSVP if you plan to attend this lunch. If your schedule becomes free the day of the lunch, then you may attend without an RSVP. This lunch is subject to cancellation when the lunch has 3 or less RSVPs.Lunch cancellation policy.

If you are not a WSBA member and would like to attend as a guest, please email Debi Arnett @ [masked]


If you have an interest in becoming a General member ($50/year) or Premier member ($100/year) of WSBA, please contact <a>Debi Arnett </a>or [masked]

 

Any non member will be removed from this site, if they RSVP and they do not attend.

results.description:
Hi All,

We're meeting at 6:00 at the tennis court of Moon park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

Olia will lead the event. Please find Olia at the court.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If a member is on the waiting list they can still come, however they may have to wait for courts to become available.
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,
results.name: Friday evening tennis - at Moon park

results.description:
Greetings Everyone!

I am back from vacation and ready to play some games!

The Friday night events were pretty popular when I left so I would like to start them up again every other Friday on the week's we don't play in the Canonsburg area.

Hope to see another great turnout!

results.description:
ATTENTION SKATERS:

MARK YOUR CALENDARS!!!

THIS IS THE FRIDAY PATROLLED SKATE ON JULY 17th. THE SKATE WILL START PROMPTLY AT 6:30 PM FOLLOWED BY THE ANNUAL "BAD TERRY BARBEQUE" (BTBBQ) AND TAILGATE PARTY IN THE JAIL TRAIL PARKING LOT STARTING AT ABOUT 8:30 PM. SEE DIRECTIONS ABOVE.

COME FOR THE SKATE OR JUST SHOW UP FOR THE BBQ AND PARTY AFTERWARDS. 

THE TRIC CLUB WILL BE PROVIDING THE MAIN FOOD ITEMS OF BURGERS, SAUSAGE AND DOGS.   THERE WILL BE A NOMINAL $ 3.00 CHARGE PER PERSON FOR MEMBERS/$5 NONMEMBERS TO HELP COVER THE COST OF THESE ITEMS. 

YOU ARE ASKED TO BRING AN ITEM TO SHARE: FOOD DISH, DESERT, FRUIT, CHIPS, DIP, SALAD, SNACKS AND; OR YOUR BEVERAGE OF CHOICE. SKATERS ARE SOME OF THE BEST COOKS WHEN IT COMES TO THESE EVENTS.

THESE BTBBQ'S ARE ALWAYS A HIGHLIGHT OF THE SKATE SEASON. COME OUT AND ENJOY THIS FUN EVENT. TALK TO FELLOW SKATERS, MEET NEW SKATERS. BRING YOUR SPOUSE, BRING A FRIEND, BRING A ROOMY, OR COME ON YOUR OWN. 

NEW SKATERS / MEMBERS ARE ESPECIALLY ENCOURAGED TO COME TO THE BBQ AND ENJOY THE FESTIVITIES EVEN THOUGH YOU MAY NOT BE PARTICIPATING IN THE FRIDAY NIGHT SKATE.

this is also a regular season NSP patrolled street weekly skate.


Intermediate skaters, helmet and wrist guards at a minimum for our safety. 2+ hours skating of downtown, S.Side, North Shore and other venues around downtown.  Trails, streets, bridges, stadiums, tunnels, Strip District, Market Square, and more! See you there! Weather permitting, of course!

Moderate pace. Urban skate. 10 to 16 miles. Mostly flat type terrain, but some gentler hills and sloped bridge decks and ramps may be encountered. Be able to maneuver in pedestrian and vehicular traffic, negotiate curbs, potholes, speed bumps and other urban amenities. Be able to brake.

It is suggested that you wear light colored clothes, carry a flashlight, or wear blinkies, or reflective items.  Part of the skate will be completed as dusk is approaching.

Be ready to roll by 6:30 PM. Get there a little early to gear up and get ready to skate!

SEE YOU THERE!

results.description:
Join us at Drinking Skeptically with our friends from the Steel City Skeptics and share a drink!

Drinking Skeptically is an informal social event designed to promote fellowship and networking among skeptics, atheists, humanists, critical-thinkers, and like-minded individuals. There is no specific topic. It is just an open discussion among fellow freethinkers about science, religion, skepticism, beer, life and leisure. Both teetotalers and those who imbibe moderately are equally welcomed. We generally meet the third or fourth Friday of each month, skipping August and December. We will return our favorite summer location at the Hofbräuhaus Pittsburgh. Go through the restaurant, out the back and down the stairs to the Beer Garden along the river. Look for Drinking Skeptically signs on the tables. We start gathering at 7 pm, but latecomers are more than welcome. Hope to see you on Friday night!
results.name: Drinking With The Skeptics

results.description:
Join us at Swisshelm most Friday nights for contra dances. This is a recurring meetup, and we will try to cancel if there is a week without a dance, but double check the schedule at www.pittsburghcontra.org which is always up-to-date.

Dances are Fridays at Swisshelm Community Center, 8pm-11pm with a beginner's lesson at 7:30.

$7 for students, $10 for the rest of us folks.

Contra dancing is hungry business, if you'd like to bring a snack to share at the break, please do!

No experience necessary, no partner necessary, just bring your feet and a smile.

Please note that most of our community is not using Meetup.com. Though it may look like nobody is attending, rest assured that there will be lots of people at the dance!
results.name: Friday Night Contra Dance

results.description:
During our meet up, we will be meditating as a group on the ‘Meditation on Twin Hearts (MTH)’. I can't emphasize enough on benefits of group meditation!

The following will be the rough agenda of our meet up!

We will first introduce ourselves and after getting to know who is who, we will have a brief description of the guided meditation.

We will do a simple set of exercise to prepare the body for  meditation. This will take about 5 mins

The main event, Meditation on Twin Hearts will take about 20 mins. Like mentioned in the group description, this is a very powerful meditation which involves very simple yet effective techniques to maximize the meditation experience.  You have to try it to feel it! Regular MTH can do wonders for physical, emotional, mental and spiritual well-being.

This will be followed by the same set of exercise and sharing of our experiences.

Then on, we can hang out and interact or go home J

Please give yourselves about 2 hours for the event.

Also, you are welcome to donate to help cover cost of the event space!

Looking forward to meeting you all !

Jeevitha 

Phone:[masked]

email: [masked]

results.description:
A WHOLE NEW CONCERT EXPERIENCE ... Theatre of Music

The Pittsburgh New Music Ensemble (PNME) offers some of the most innovative performances during summer weekends at City Theater in the South Side.  These acclaimed performances often include world premieres of new works showcasing contemporary music, dance movements, theatre, and cutting-edge video artistry.

The PNME involves unique collaborations among musicians, artists, and composers from Pittsburgh and throughout North America. Since its founding in 1976, PNME has commissioned and premiered over 200 works. 

The 2015 PNME Season begins the weekend of July 10-11, and continues for four weekends until July 31 - August 1.

﻿To check out the entire PNME 40th Anniversary season, please visit http://www.pnme.org/season/

Check out these great preview articles about PNME's upcoming concerts this summer http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/music/2015/07/07/Preview-PNME-celebrates-40-years-of-charting-new-music-territory/stories/201507070057

http://triblive.com/aande/music/8665704-74/music-ensemble-season#axzz3fSLXkkAg

Each PNME concert is unique. But to check out an example video of what these PNME concerts may be like, please visit http://www.pnme.org/videos/ or http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KrJgpZm8t00

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KrJgpZm8t00

PNME is also excited to start a new "BYO Bottle of Wine" tradition this season! Bring whatever you wish and we can cork it after the performances, while you hang with the artists and fellow audience members! Each show, a different artist or board member will prepare a food delicacy to share with you. Experience the show, then let us get to know you better over a glass of wine and some nibbles! http://www.pnme.org/news-events/

Concert #2 (July 17-18) "PREMIERES AND PULITZERS"

Two world premieres of PNME commissions by both our founder David Stock, and recent Prix de Rome winner Daniel Visconti are paired with the 2009 Pulitzer Prize winning Double Sextet by American Master Steve Reich.

These PNME Concerts are typically 1-2 hours, and so it is not too long of an evening -- and is easily incorporated with other plans, such as dining before the show or going out for a drink afterwards.

In addition, if you have never been to a PNME concert before, PNME graciously offers first timers a free ticket!! First timers can pick up their free ticket at the Box Office beginning at 7 PM (one hour before the concert). See below for details.

Also, as another discount bonus -- if you've been to PNME before and bring someone new, you'll pay just $15 ticket.

And if you bring two first timers, then you go for free!

MEETUP Considerations -- When you RSVP, please indicate which performance date you prefer (Friday July 17 or Saturday July 18)

TICKETS (If you're not a first timer, and need to buy tickets)

Please visit http://www.pnme.org/tickets or call ShowClix 1.888.71.TICKETS [masked])

Season Package: save up to 40% with 4 tickets for $80 (or $40 students/seniors) Must be ordered in advance. Applies to weekend concerts only - 4 tickets total. Choose Friday nights or Saturday nights. Easy ticket replacement, exchange, and donation options.

Single Tickets:

◦General Admission: $25 advance

◦Students: $10 advance

*Seniors: $15 advance

Student discount applies to ages 26 & younger, or those with a full-time student ID; Senior discount applies to ages 62 & older. Limit one ticket per I.D.

•First Limers*: FREE! – only available at door beginning at 7 PM

*A first limer is a first time attendee.

*And if you bring a first timer, then you pay only $15 at the door!

*And if you bring two first timers, then you go for free!

For more information, please visit the PNME Homepage with links to videos, music, and reviews http://pnme.org

results.description:
The Pittsburgh Vintage Grand Prix is our nation's premier vintage race event! For 32 consecutive years Pittsburgh has hosted the only vintage race event held on city streets where flock to Schenley Park to watch 150 racers compete through the stone walled streets of Schenley Park. The event has grown into a motorsport festival that includes car shows, parades, a blacktie gala, countryside tour and historic races at Pittsburgh International Race Complex.

The Pittsburgh Vintage Grand Prix Association is a 501 (c) (3) non-profit organization with a mission to hold a world-class vintage automotive event for charity. Since 1983 this volunteer-driven event has raised almost $4 million for the Autism Society of Pittsburgh and Allegheny Valley School, including an all-time record of $360,000 in 2014.

The upcoming 2015 Race Week culminates with our 33rd annual vintage races and car shows at Schenley Park on the weekend of July 18th & 19th.

http://www.pvgp.org/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Vintage_Grand_Prix
results.name: Pittsburgh Vintage Grand Prix‏

group.name: Free and Almost Free in Pittsburgh

results.description:
We will meet at 8am at the parking lot on Second Ave near the 10th Street Bridge!  (see below for directions)

At 10am we'll be police-escorted into Schenley Park for the car show & vintage races! 

Lunch will be provided on Saturday by MINI of Pittsburgh.  

Register with PVGP HERE. The cost is $30/car. Registration closes July 16th!! 


Directions to Second Ave Parking Lot:  Google Maps Link

From Cranberry Township & North 

Take I 279 South towards Pittsburgh. Take exit 2A to merge onto I 579 South towards the Veterans Bridge.  Take the 7th Ave exit towards 6th Ave & Downtown.  Keep left at the fork and follow signs for Console Cetner 6th Ave and merge onto Bigelow Blvd. Continue onto Bigelow Square.  Turn left onto Sixth Ave then Left onto Forbes Ave.  Turn right onto <a>S 10th Street / Armstrong Tunnel</a>and then left onto Second Ave. There will be a stop light at the parking lot, you'll make a right into it.  

From Monroeville & South/East

You'll want to come in I 376 West through the Squirrel Hill Tunnel. Take Exit 73A for PA 885 South towards Glenwood. You'll come off the ramp and make a Right onto Bates St. Follow Bates under the overpass and make a Right at the red light onto Second Ave. Follow Second Ave along the river for ~1.5 miles. There is a stop light at the entrance to the parking lot (it'll be on your left). If you make it to the <a>10th Street</a> Bridge intersection - you've gone too far! 

From Washington and South/West 

Come in I 79 North and take exit 59A to merge onto I 376 East towards Pittsburgh.  Keep right to stay on I 376 E.  Take exit 71A on the left for Grant St then turn right onto Second Ave.  The parking lot will be on your right.

results.description: Drawn from the remarkable collections of the National Museum Wales, this exhibition at the Frick Art & Historical Center traces the development of landscape painting in Britain through the Industrial Revolution and the eras of Romanticism, Impressionism, and Modernism, to the postmodern and post-industrial imagery of today. More than 60 works of art, including major oil paintings, watercolors, drawings, and photographs, offer fresh insight into the changing relationship between artists and the landscape, as well as the evolving tastes of wealthy collectors. Join the St. David's Society of Pittsburgh for a walk through the exhibit.

For more information about the GLMF, please click here. http://medievalfaire.com/index.htm

For more information about the NCG-GPA's experiences at the GLMF please click here. http://www.meetup.com/NCGGreaterPittsburghArea/boards/thread/7321988/60/

We at the NCG-GPA strongly recommend that you attend this event. I, Brom B. (Brutal Brom) have been attending Renaissance Festivals/Faires since 1994. Over the years I have developed a strong relationship with many of the local faires/festivals as well as an affinity for the fine and talented performers that bring such magic and mirth to life for us all to enjoy.

Also, if you attend any of the dates, please feel free to upload photos of your time there.
results.name: Great Lakes Medieval Faire 2015 season : Everyone is encouraged to attend!

results.description:
Please join us for a wonderful family performance of "The True Story of the Three Little Pigs" which will delight both kids and adults.  The first performance will be held on Saturday, July 11 at 11:00 am at the Beaux Arts Ballroom in the Twentieth Century Club in Oakland. And then this show will be repeated every Saturday morning (July 11, 18, 25 and August 1) during the Opera Theater SummerFest. 

Immerse the whole family in this delightful take on a classic story!  So, did the wolf just get a bad rap? This musical adventure is an attention-friendly 40 minute fun show and a great introduction to opera for children of all ages.  Kids get to sit within a few feet of the singers in the intimate Beaux Arts Ballroom for this up-close and casual performance.


With familiar characters (and some you didn't expect!), this is the perfect opportunity for the whole family to discover together the joys of music drama. 

After the show, families can stay to enjoy piggy-themed crafts and activities, complimentary popcorn and lemonade, and Q&As and photo opps with cast members!


Surprises abound!

Please see the Opera Theater SummerFest website for details on special pre-show guests, like composer Wallace DePue, and plan to enjoy piggy-themed activities and crafts after the show.


Free lemonade and popcorn, fun (including photo opps with singers/characters and others), and surprises abound!  Directed by Dennis Robinson, Jr.


Performances:
• Saturday 11 July at 11:00 am
• Saturday 18 July at 11:00 am
• Saturday 25 July at 11:00 am
• Saturday 01 August at 11:00 am 

This show is performed in under an hour (with no intermission) and so there would be plenty of time for friends/family to enjoy the rest of their Saturday. And there are many great places people could check out with a just few minutes walk, such as the Carnegie Museums, Schenley Plaza, Soldiers & Sailors Museum, Phipps Conservatory, Carnegie Library (where there are free activities during weekend afternoons), Cathedral of Learning Nationality Rooms, etc. as well as many restaurants in Oakland.

As always, it is also fine if you wish to enjoy this performance on your own with family and friends instead.


Tickets:
Adults: $10
Children: $5 

Groups of 8 or more save 10%
Groups of 20 or more save 20% 

Other ticket discount options are also available. See the last section below for more detail.


For more information and to buy tickets:
http://otsummerfest.org/events/the-three-pigs 


More on Opera Theater SummerFest:
SummerFest 2015 is four weeks of opera and musicals sung in English, an international recital series, a children's opera, cabarets and more! Enjoy the world premiere of our newly-commissioned A New Kind of Fallout, two versions of Mozart's The Marriage of Figaro, Richard Strauss' enchanting Capriccio, and Damn Yankees, the all-American musical. Performances take place at the historic Twentieth Century Club in Oakland from July 10 – August 2. http://otsummerfest.org/events/calendar 

Check out these great articles about the Opera Theater SummerFest and the various shows during July 10 – August 2 http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/music/2015/07/09/Opera-Theater-s-SummerFest-offers-unusual-productions-to-attract-new-audiences/stories/201507090084

http://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/opera-theaters-summerfest-features-rachel-carson-inspired-work/Content?oid=1838370

We've also added a Discussion Board forum for those that may wish to suggest some shows where perhaps some smaller groups of people could get together depending on their schedules. Please visit http://www.meetup.com/Art-lovers/messages/boards/thread/49092583

For more information about the beautiful, historic Twentieth Century Club, please visit http://www.thetwentiethcenturyclub.com/index.html


Directions/Parking/Dining:
There is some street parking but most park across the street at Soldiers and Sailors. Detailed directions and dining options: http://otsummerfest.org/events/plan-your-visit

Other Ticket Discount Options

If anyone is interested in the Saturday, July 18 or Saturday, July 25 morning performances, there are additional discount tickets of $2.50 children and $7.50 adults (including ticket handling fees) offered through the Goldstar discount ticketing company http://www.goldstar.com/events/pittsburgh-pa/the-true-story-of-the-3-little-pigs-tickets

FYI, here are other upcoming shows where Goldstar has access to discount tickets including other shows as part of the Opera Theater SummerFest http://www.goldstar.com/pittsburgh/events/?page=3&mode=infinite While Goldstar is not a substitute for more traditional savings/benefits through the usual subscriptions or other discount offers, it is a relatively new option for Pittsburgh. For more background/FAQ about Goldstar, including links to articles from the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, and Forbes, please visit http://www.goldstar.com/company Please note that Goldstar is free to join.

results.description:
We're going to run kickball every OTHER Saturday but I'm going to try to run some other events during the off-weeks.  Big Ball is more fun than it looks.  Check out the details below.  No spikes or cleats are permitted for this game.  Come join us for this unique but fun game!

This game got quite popular last year and was requested as our Meetup of the week for 7 straight weeks.   

The name of the game is Big Ball. I created this game during my junior year at IUP. The best way to describe the game is that it's a mix between Soccer and Ultimate Frisbee but we use a ball that's about 45" in diameter. We played it every week for 2 years on the practice soccer field. There is no physical contact with other players permitted but you can use the ball however you want. Any part of your body can touch the ball and there's no height limit on the goals. Also, NO CLEATS OR SPIKES ALLOWED!


To see a video of this game in action from 3 years ago, check it out here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=deBQzfRsBg0

We will be playing this game at Armstrong Field near 12th St and Sarah St.

Here are some more details & rules.

Field size we need is about 60 - 70 yards based on how many players we get (best games are at least 7 vs 7)

There are 3 lines that matter in the game...the goal line on each side and the line at the center of the field. There are no out of bounds lines on the sides of the field.

Players can dribble, roll, kick, throw or carry the ball for 3 steps

The goals are 12 feet wide and there is no height limit on the goal. The game relies heavily on defense. There are also no regulations for goalies or a goalie box. This means your goalie can play mid field if he wants or you can even have 3 goalies...they can even piggyback on each other to be "taller" if they want. You just lose those additional players in the field

Both teams start the game and after each goal at mid-field. The team that wins the coin toss or just got scored on start with the ball. As soon as anything crosses mid-field (the ball OR one of your players that's getting a running start) the other team is allowed to cross the line and start playing defense.

As mentioned above, there is no physical contact with other players but you can use the ball however you want. If you're in the process of taking your 3 steps you can plow people over with the ball. If someone is charging you, you can kick the ball at them, you can hit people with the ball...I just prefer you don't aim for the head.

If you do actually blatantly contact someone you get a warning and a 2 minute penalty. Second offense in the same game gets you ejected from the game. This only happened once in 2 years of playing as the ball does a good enough job of not getting players TOO close to each other...

The ball is built like an exercise ball but it's VERY heavy. I would strongly advise players not try to punch the ball while it's in the air, hit it with one arm or kick it with your feet as it could easily result in an injury or twisting of the body. On that note, it's easiest to "kick" the ball with your knees or thigh, hit it with two hands punching close together or hit with the forearms while hands are clenched at the fists.

We sometimes have players get into a "scrum" around the ball and it doesn't move for a while. If that happens and the ball doesn't move for 3 - 5 seconds we'll have a jump ball from where the "scrum" took place.

Games are normally played until 11 and we switch sides of the field when one team scores 6. We usually take a little half-time break at that point too.

We have had many girls play the sport and they loved it.  A few of them even had trouble picking the ball up but they still loved the game. Some of them were actually our most die-hard players.

We normally start every game kicking and throwing the ball in a circle to get everyone warmed up for how big and heavy the ball actually is

The game is actually the most fun in the rain because of our most important rule...

NO CLEATS OR SPIKES OF ANY KIND! All players must wear tennis shoes or some other kind of non-grip shoe so they don't have any advantage in the dirt or grass. That's the way we've always played and I feel that makes everyone very even when it comes to maneuverability on the field. You can only imagine what some rain, puddles and slick grass add to a game where no one has traction. Good times.

Join us on Saturday, July 18th at noon at Armstrong Field in the South Side for a game of Big Ball.  Just show up to the park to play and bring some friends.  Don't forget the number one rule...No SPIKES!

results.description:
Washington, PA’s, café, Fortuitea, has gone vegan! Let’s meetup for lunch and support them in this wonderful development.

That’s right—from pizza to gourmet mac n’ cheese, savory soups and sandwiches to sweet treats, feel free to order anything on their newly expanded menu—it’s all animal product-free! You can also enjoy a British-style afternoon tea—choose from 100 varieties of loose leaf teas and freshly ground coffees! And for the gluten-sensitive among us, Fortuitea has your needs covered, too. Nearly everything on the menu can be made gluten-free!

Does this sound awesome or what?

Fortuitea/Quail Acres is located a half mile from the Tanger Outlet mall, so you can make this a full day-event if you wish.

For more info including DIRECTIONS, Visit The Shoppes at Quail Acres' website at: http://www.quailacres.com/contact.html

Visit Fortuitea's website at: http://www.fortuiteacafe.com/
results.name: Lunch at Fortuitea Cafe! (Now All-Vegan!!)

results.description:
CLICK HERE


Join Vanessa from Sweat and Butter, our hiking guide, Judy, and yoga expert, Jen to get fit and connect with nature. Our hike will begin with our guest speaker, Vanessa as she shares tips to enjoy fitness and fun in the outdoors. After her talk, we will enjoy a short hike followed by a yoga practice to invigorate, then renew.

Connect with nature, hike and practice yoga on this amazing outing with experts from our L.L.Bean Pittsburgh Retail Store. We'll hike the beautiful trails of North Park followed by an invigorating yoga session, infused with the same techniques we use for our Stand-Up Paddleboarding Courses in the summer. Please make sure you wear appropriate hiking clothing, waterproof footwear (if possible) and dress for the weather (layers; no cotton.) Please bring a small day pack with extra clothes, snacks, water and any personal medications you may need. Ages 8 and up are welcome. Hope to see you on the trail!


Learn the skills for a lifetime of adventure:
  • L.L.Bean Outdoor Discovery Schools  LLBean.com/Adventure
</a>

Thank you for your interest in our free "Yoga Hike Outing." L.L.Bean has a new centralized reservation system. To guarantee your space, you must first confirm your reservation on our new centralized reservation system, and if appropriate, fill out a participant agreement. Please visit <a href="http://www.llbean.com/pittsburgh">www.llbean.com/pittsburgh, find this event on the "Event Calendar", and register. We look forward to seeing you!

Activity Level: 
Physical Ability/Cardiovascular Demand: Easy 
Level of Experience: Intro

What to Bring: 
Dress comfortably for both hiking and yoga 
Hiking Boots or Trail Shoes 
Day Pack 
Water to stay hydrated 
Snacks 
Yoga Mat, Towel or Blanket 
Completed and signed L.L.Bean participant agreement--> Click Here

Optional: Optics, Lip Balm, Camera, Walking Stick or Trekking Poles, Personal Medicines

Minimum Age 8: This outing is open to ages 8 and above. Children 8 to 14 years of age need to be accompanied by a participating adult. Children 15 to 17 years old can participate alone after their parent has signed the L.L.Bean participant agreement for minors.


Dog-friendly: Leashed, people friendly, vaccinated, well socialized outdoor dogs are welcome on this hike outing.

Need help preparing for your next adventure? Visit L.L.Bean Store at Ross Park Mall and ask to speak with an Outdoor Product Specialist. L.L.Bean will fit you with the right clothing and gear for all of life's adventures.

L.L.Bean Store at Ross Park Mall
1000 Ross Park Mall Drive (Map)
Pittsburgh, PA  15237
L.L.Bean Outdoor Discovery Schools
Website | Meetup | Twitter | Facebook
<a href="http://www.llbean.com/llb/ods"></a>

results.description:
Calling all Plant Warriors!!!   I'd like to invite everyone to a giant gathering of like minds!

The goal for this meetup is just to get as many people in this group together at one time, to really meet one another and bounce ideas around for future classes!

(The image above is a shot of the pavilion where we can all meet. It may or may not be already taken that day, but there is a large area all around it that we can use if we need to!)


It'll be laid-back, nothing required but just to show up!  If you're feeling up for it, feel free to bring a snack (for yourself or to share!)  and I will be providing cold water for all!

We can all take a little plant walk stroll around the park a bit too if we feel so inclined.


I may work out a few activities for us to do and appreciate any input & thoughts!   (So far I'm thinking maybe a short plant walk, a brief or more in-depth discussion of the past and present of Boyce-Mayview Park, possibly a short "how to make your own medicines" basics talk, a "botany basics" talk, an "invasive" plant talk, and....????)  My wheels are spinning, and let me know if yours are too!

If we have enough ideas and enough interest, we can definitely make for an earlier start time to fit it all in!

I'd just really like to get all of you beautiful people together in the community spirit.

Come on out!  This isn't to be missed!
results.name: South Hills Wild Edibles Plant Group Gathering! (Free!)

results.description:
我们为什么要聚餐？因为我们要成为朋友！
Why do we eat together? To be friends!

我们的最大的愿望就是在匹兹堡认识更多的人，成为彼此的朋友！希望在三年之后，我们会看到自己的手机通信录里面被匹兹堡的朋友们填满，心里常常会有几个名字会突然跳出来，发个短信问候一句，打个电话约出来聊聊天。

关于这次晚餐About this meetup：

1. 晚餐费用均摊，这家餐馆是点餐共享制，所以每人限点一道菜，预计每人十八元左右。We will share the dinner cost evenly. This restaurant is order and share style, each person can pick one dish at most, the anticipated price is about $18 each person.

2. 如果你这次有事情来不了，不用担心，我们每个月的第三个周六晚上都会约大家晚餐。If you cannot come this time, don't worry. We will invite all of you for dinner every third Saturday of each month.

3. 每次晚餐我们会在前半个小时安排一个固定话题让大家轮流分享，或者一个简单的游戏让大家参与。之后的时间大家自行交流，自由离开。There will be a half hour sharing or game at the beginning of the dinner. The rest of the time will be your free social hour. You can leave at any time you like.
results.name: Dinner Meetup at Sichuan Gourmet 7/18 6:00pm

results.description:
Dance Lesson, Wine Session ... Saturday Night Fever theme!
Edit Cancel Print ticket Export Tell a friend Share
Saturday, July 18, 2015
6:00 PM to 10:00 PM
Pittsburgh Dance Center
4765 Liberty Ave., Pittsburgh, PA (edit map)

Please join us as we continue the 'Dance Lesson, Wine Session' series at the Pittsburgh Dance Center located in the heart of Bloomfield.

Between 6-6:30 pm, we will start with byowine tasting and entertainment by PDC Aerial Silks Performers. Light snacks and refreshments will also be provided.

However, people also have the option to meetup beforehand for happy hour specials at one of the many options in Bloomfield. Please post comments below if anyone would like to meet earlier (perhaps 5-6 PM) or have some suggestions of favorite bar/restaurant in Bloomfield to check out before going to the PDC.

Around 6:45 PM, there will be an introductory Hustle class to get the dance started. The first lesson will be followed by a break so the group may enjoy more food/wine and socializing --- and we'll be playing a number of disco and 70's dance favorites to continue dancing until around 10 PM. Of course requests for other types of dances/songs are always welcome. Like the previous dances, we will have a chance to change partners so we all get to meet and have a chance to dance so it is not necessary to bring a partner although everyone is certainly welcome to invite friends.

The fun dance lessons will be suitable for beginners, with all levels welcome. The doors will open around 6 PM so we'll have a bit more time for socializing before the first lesson begins.

The dance class/evening is only $10. What a great deal!!

As a reminder, this event is BYOwine which has been so popular in the past as guests have a chance to try so many different wines! Please wear something comfortable -- or surprise us with some Saturday Night Fever attire!

With so many people in the Meetup, sometimes it can be challenge meeting/mingling, especially for relatively new members when attending other events at busy art galleries, outdoor festivals, and performances at large venues such as the Benedum. So perhaps a series of fun activities that bring lots of people together would also help with introductions and spotting other members at future events.

After the socializing period and PDC Aerial Silks performance, we will have the first hustle lesson around 6:45 PM.

After the first 30-minute lesson, people will have the option to continue dancing until around 10 PM or simply enjoy more wines, snacks, good conversation, and lots of laughs. There will also be a hustle line dance lesson as well later in the night if the crowd is into it. And there will even be mini-class lessons to some of your favorite beats for those that are interested!!

This will be a fantastic event bringing people together -- Meetup groups, PDC clients, and dance enthusiasts.

This 'Dance Lesson, Wine Session' series has been a lot of fun (for those that may have attended the earlier Meetup events last year on April 3, May 8, June 29, August 24, September 25, October 26, November 16, December 21, or earlier this year on January 31, March 20, May 1, June 5) -- so having it with the Saturday Night Fever theme should be a great time for everyone.

While Pittsburgh has a vibrant cultural scene, including classical and contemporary dance, this is our chance to experience being a bit more than spectators while learning more about the art of dance.

Unlike a restaurant where people spend most of the time talking with those seated nearby, the 'Dance Lesson, Wine Lesson' will be less formal so people should be able to meet many others while enjoying the group dance lesson and sharing wine.

While there are other Meetup groups and organizations in the region that are specifically focused on dance, this event is also an opportunity for people to see if they might enjoy taking up dance in a relaxed, informal atmosphere. Because some might be more comfortable bringing a friend for the dance lesson, guests are certainly welcome. So when you RSVP, please indicate if you'll bringing one or more friends.

This event costs only $10/person -- please bring cash at the door -- and is BYOwine.
But to make the wine appreciation session more interesting, please feel free to bring one of your favorite bottles of wine -- or perhaps something you've never tried before -- with an emphasis on value wines in the $12/bottle range.
For those that live close to the larger state stores, this might be a chance to check out one of the Chairmen's Selection wines.

It would be fantastic if this event included a variety of wines for the group to try.

And if you don't drink, that is certainly OK as this event is about having fun, bringing lots of people together, and learning a little more about ballroom dance. We hope to see everyone on Saturday, July 18!

For more information on the Pittsburgh Dance Center, please visit http://www.pittsburghdancecenter.com

Note -- People also gave the option to meetup beforehand for happy hour specials at one of the many options in Bloomfield. Please post comments below if anyone would like to meet earlier (perhaps 5-6 PM) or have some suggestions of favorite bars/restaurants in Bloomfield.
results.name: Dance Lesson, Wine Session...Saturday Night Fever!

Unlike a restaurant where people spend most of the time talking with those seated nearby, the 'Dance Lesson, Wine Lesson' will be less formal so people should be able to meet many others while enjoying the group dance lesson and sharing wine.

While there are other Meetup groups and organizations in the region that are specifically focused on dance, this event is also an opportunity for people to see if they might enjoy taking up dance in a relaxed, informal atmosphere.  

Because some might be more comfortable bringing a friend for the dance lesson, guests are certainly welcome. So when you RSVP, please indicate if you'll bringing one or more friends.

This event costs only $10/person -- please bring cash at the door -- and is BYOwine. 


But to make the wine appreciation session more interesting, please feel free to bring one of your favorite bottles of wine -- or perhaps something you've never tried before -- with an emphasis on value wines in the $12/bottle range. 


For those that live close to the larger state stores, this might be a chance to check out one of the Chairmen's Selection wines.

It would be fantastic if this event included a variety of wines for the group to try.

And if you don't drink, that is certainly OK as this event is about having fun, bringing lots of people together, and learning a little more about ballroom dance. 

We hope to see everyone on Saturday, July 18!

For more information on the Pittsburgh Dance Center, please visit http://www.pittsburghdancecenter.com

Note -- People also gave the option to meetup beforehand for happy hour specials at one of the many options in Bloomfield. Please post comments below if anyone would like to meet earlier (perhaps 5-6 PM) or have some suggestions of favorite bars/restaurants in Bloomfield.
results.name: Dance Lesson, Wine Session ... Saturday Night Fever!
