results.description:
This is an online event ---a photo album only.

Put your photo and/or design skills into creating a logo we can apply to T-shirts (or other items.) Wear the T-shirts to events to help members find each other ---or wear them anywhere to proudly show your membership.

The design can be applied to a T-shirt of choice ---lots of choices of price, style and color.  And the site we will use has frequent discount sales, too. 


We will post them on zazzle.com and all proceeds will be donated to the Photo Safari. (The proceeds are only about 10% of sales.  It probably won't amount to much, but every little bit will help the group.)

Post your designs, as many as you wish, to the album on or before Sept 30.  (If you have a design idea, but don't have the skills to use necessary software, see an alternative below.)


After Sept 30th, we will send an email to explain how members can vote to choose a logo design from those posted.

Requirements for the design:


Minimum size should be 9"X12" at 300ppi, portrait or landscape format, or a square or round design that is at least 12"X12".


Each should include the text "Pittsburgh Photo Safari Meetup" prominently in the design. 

You can create a traditional photographic-themed image or an iconic image of Pittsburgh, or you can let your imagination run wild.  Another possibility is to create a generic design into which each member could place his/her own photo image.


Use your own photo(s), your manipulated photo(s), your own illustration, graphic design, or cartoon. If you use clip art or stock photos, make sure you have the right to use them royalty-free. If a person is recognizable, make sure you have a model release. (Do not use Pgh sports-team logos or images. They are copyrighted and aggressively protected.) 

The design should look good on white or light-colored shirts. On colored shirts, white areas will be blank so the color of the shirt will show through. (Later, we may ask the creator of the chosen design to come up with an alternative for dark shirts where white will be printed in white ink.)  

If you use software that includes layers, please keep at least one copy with all your layers so we can easily tweak the design, if necessary. If, for example, you use Photoshop, save one copy in Photoshop format, preserving your layers. 

If the background will be blank, it is best to save another copy in png format.  If the background will be part of the design you can save it in jpg as well as the Photoshop copy.  Optional, if you want to post your image in a smaller format online, you can save it again in a smaller jpg format to post in this album. Eventually the chosen image will be emailed to me to post at zazzle.com. If it is too large to email, it can be mailed to me on a CD or DVD. 

Alternative: If you have a great design idea, but you don't have the skill to use Photoshop, Illustrator or other software to perfect it, post a photo, a sketch (rough or detailed) or even a scan of a similar logo you've seen.  In a caption or comment, suggest that others with the necessary skills use it as a starting point to create a group logo. Explain your idea more fully in a comment, if necessary. State clearly that you are giving permission for others to use your idea.

If you have an iconic image of Pittsburgh which you are willing to offer for use in a design, post it with a caption or comment giving permission for others to use it in a logo.

If you run with a photo or design idea posted by someone else, please add a caption "From a design idea (or photo) by ______" so the credit will go to both of you. DO NOT use someone else's photo or design unless the member has stated that others have permission to use it.

_____________

Zazzle.com is a great place for you to sell your own work, too. You can set up your own store to create products for yourself or to sell your photos or art work as prints, greeting cards, postcards, and a zillion other products (T-shirts, mugs, caps, mousepads, notebook covers, tote bags, iPhone covers, real postage stamps, stationary, neckties, flip-flops, skate boards, and much more.)
results.name: Design a Pittsburgh Photo Safari Logo 7/19 - 9/30/15

results.description:
The July assembly is coming soon! The theme of the month will be "Humanism" - what it is, and what it can be. When asked to describe Humanism, self identifying humanists are often at a loss for words. The concept itself is a bit nebulous, and lacks clarity in the broader culture. How can we best understand and describe Humanism as a life philosophy? What are its key principles or components? What does it mean to be Humanist, anyway?  

Our speaker, Akshat Gupta from the Carnegie Mellon Humanist League, will attempt to answer some of these questions that nag the Humanist community by proposing three simple components that allow us to understand and describe Humanism as a coherent philosophical worldview and social movement.

As usual we will be rocking out to music, building community, eating cookies, and drinking tea!

We’re always looking for people to get involved! If you’re interested in speaking, leading a song, or doing a reading for a future assembly, send our content coordinator Alex an email at [masked]

results.description:
St. Mary was founded in 1855 as a German parish. The origin of the parish can be traced to the settling of German farmers next to Chartiers Creek in the 1840's. These settlers were required to travel to St. Philomena or St. Michael in Pittsburgh or St. Philip in Crafton to attend Mass. By 1855, enough Catholic families had settled in the area to make the establishment of a parish feasible. In that year, the bishop granted their petition for a parish. The parish outgrew two previous churches before purchasing land and relocating to its present location to build the third church that we see today.

William P. Ginther was commissioned to design the new church. William P. Ginther (FAIA) (1858–1933) was an American architect based in Akron, Ohio. He was a prolific designer of Roman Catholic churches, schools and rectories throughout Ohio, Pennsylvania, Indiana, California, Virginia and New York. In Pittsburgh, Ginther also designed the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church in Polish Hill and Saint Philip Church in Crafton.

With its stone trim, twin Gothic steeples and German stained-glass windows, Saint Mary Church is a quintessential Ginther-designed architectural treasure. Visit this website to view images of this masterpiece: http://www.eyeonheritage.com/mary.html.
results.name: Pittsburgh Mass Mob XII

group.name: Free and Almost Free in Pittsburgh

results.description:
St. Mary was founded in 1855 as a German parish.  The origin of the parish can be traced to the settling of German farmers next to Chartiers Creek in the 1840's.  These settlers were required to travel to St. Philomena or St. Michael in Pittsburgh or St. Philip in Crafton to attend Mass.  By 1855, enough Catholic families had settled in the area to make the establishment of a parish feasible.  In that year, the bishop granted their petition for a parish. 

The parish outgrew two previous churches before purchasing land and relocating to its present location to build the third church that we see today.

William P. Ginther was commissioned to design the new church. William P. Ginther (FAIA) (1858–1933) was an American architect based in Akron, Ohio. He was a prolific designer of Roman Catholic churches, schools and rectories throughout Ohio, Pennsylvania, Indiana, California, Virginia and New York. In Pittsburgh, Ginther also designed the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church in Polish Hill and Saint Philip Church in Crafton.

With its stone trim, twin Gothic steeples and German stained-glass windows, Saint Mary Church is a quintessential Ginther-designed architectural treasure. The church is modeled after the Cologne Cathedral in Cologne, Germany that survived the many air raids of World War II. Visit this website to view images of this masterpiece: http://www.eyeonheritage.com/mary.html.

As the growth of population in the nineteenth century led to the creation of the parish, the loss of population in McKees Rocks at the end of the twentieth century led to its suppression.  In 1993, St. Mary Help of Christians was merged with six other parishes to form the new St. John of God parish.  St. Mary church remains open and serves the new parish.

Join your Pittsburgh Mass Mob friends as we enjoy Mass at this exquisite example of German-inspired Gothic religious architecture.  Come support our brothers and sisters in Catholic faith and extend the hand of grace and friendship.

A tour of the church will follow the Mass. Bring along your family and friends. There is something to see here for everyone.

Bring along your cameras because this church is a gem of the Diocese of Pittsburgh!

results.description:
Hello everyone! Had so much fun at the super successful Verde dinner so I wanted to do another great MeetUp where us plant-powered folks normally can't - A FARM DINNER!!! I am doing a Churchview Farm Dinner this summer and early bird tickets are now available! For $95, it will be a 5-8 course dinner with pairings, enjoying the full bounty of the farm season. This would be a perfect gift for the holiday season. I'm already planning a menu and I promise that it will be phenomenal. It's the only vegan farm dinner in Pittsburgh and I'm so honored to be invited to do it!

Come one, come all! Let's hang out again! There are ONLY 45 seats available (we had over 150 people come to the Verde dinner!) This is also a more intimate venue than Verde, where we had a tough time trying to find the Pgh Vegan Meetup folks. This time, I'm going to reserve a section for the MeetUp so we can all be near each other (unless we take over the entire dinner :) Thanks all and I hope to see you there! Happy holidays!

https://churchviewfarmpgh.squarespace.com/dinners/
results.name: Vegan Farm Dinner at Churchview Farms

results.description:
2 Rules for the meet up:

1) No solicitation of services *cool if someone comes to you but consultants/lawyers/coaches beware, any sales pitches and you'll have to find a new Monday ritual

2) Make sure to state whether what you are saying is an opinion or fact (both very much welcome) so to not confuse anyone about where the point of view comes from

Location change: Repair The World - 6022 Broad St. (Around the corner from Zeke's Coffee - grab your coffee from there and head over)

Share or listen to ideas but don't be fooled this is not startup therapy or feeding the ego this is about getting to work and removing the obstacles to make your idea a reality.

All entrepreneurs are welcome and it's not uncommon for us to have musicians, artists, chefs, writers, developers, renovators, or just about anyone else you can think of join the conversation.
results.name: Get your ideas or business UNSTUCK!

results.description:
Hello fellow real estate investor! Summer is upon us and we're all set for our 3nd annual real estate investors summer picnic!

This event is a collaboration of three local real estate groups: Our group, Otis DiCerbo's group out of Irwin, and Brandon Yeager's group out of the Greensburg area.

The picnic will be at Indian Lake Park in North Huntingdon - Seneca Pavilion. Start time is 5Pm'ish. If you cannot make it until 6 or later due to your work schedule you're still welcome to stop out. It is free to attend and each group will be bringing something. Our group's contribution is to bring a side dish... potato salad, fruit salad, macaroni salad, cole slaw, baked beans... you get the idea. Everything else will be provided by the other groups.

This is a family picnic, so please bring the kiddos with you. They had a great time last year! We will have games and such for them and we will be having a fishing derby - rods & bait will be provided by the park.

Looking forward to a fun time! Please RSVP if you plan to attend. As always, you're welcome to bring a friend or two.

Until then my friend,

Jerry & Pam - Organizers

C (412)[masked]

PS. The picnic is in lieu of our regular monthly meeting. We WILL NOT be getting together at Christina's in White Oak in July.

PSS. If you use the address 2499 Clay Pike that will bring you to a back entrance to the park (Brokers Lane). Turn on Brokers Lane and go a short distance and the Seneca Pavilion will be on the your left. There is a large gravel parking area that you'll be turning in to.
results.how_to_find_us: 2499 Clay Pike Irwin, Pa 15642
results.name: 3rd Annual Investor Summer Picnic!

results.description: Our 3rd annual summer picnic is scheduled for Monday, July 20th, 2015 beginning at 5pm. Location is Indian Lake Park, Seneca Pavilion, Clay Pike, North Huntingdon, PA 15642. We will be teaming up with our friends from the Westmoreland Investor group led by Brandon Yeager and the Pittsburgh Real Estate Investor Group led by Jerry Kiasonak. Family members, children most welcome. Food, fun, games and lots of networking opportunities...hope to see you there.

results.description:
Hi All,

We're meeting at 6:00 at the tennis court of Moon park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If a member is on the waiting list they can still come, however they may have to wait for courts to become available.
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,

results.description:
Want to enhance your career path through an MBA degree? What is the real value? Your questions will be answered from different viewpoints!

What impact will an MBA bring to your career? Are you interested in pursuing the degree but have no clue where to start? How do you select a program? Dilemma between full time and part time? How to get into the program you desire? What should you expect once school starts? Where is the work/school/life balance?

These are just some of the questions that will be answered during this panel discussion, jointly hosted by PYP and Carnegie Mellon's Tepper School of Business. Prospective students will be guided and get to learn various perspectives from our special guest speakers.

Cost:
Free for Members
$5 for nonmembers (Special promo for continuing education)


To Register:
Please visit pyp.org/events

*Please note that using meetup.com to RSVP to our events does not count as an official registration. All interested parties must register on pyp.org/events.
results.name: Empower Your Career through an MBA

Who's up: Nick

 

We are being offered free use of the meeting room, and are therefore guests.  The Children's Institute has asked that we not park in their lot (handicapped members excepted; if you have plates or a placard, you can park in the lot), but park on the street.  There is parking on Shady Avenue.  The main entrance is on Shady.  You must register with the reception desk.  We meet in Room 220, which can be difficult to find if you've not been there before, so it is best to arrive early so the intrepid, experienced members who already know the way can lead you.  Bringing breadcrumbs is optional, but be aware that they clean and polish the floors in the evenings, and this is even more effective than birds for removing trails of breadcrumbs.  If you arrive late for your first meeting, ask the receptionist for directions.  Also be aware that anyone found wandering the halls muttering "220, 220..." after 9pm will be swept out with the trash.

results.description:
Come and play ukulele with us at the Unitarian Universalist Church of the North Hills on the first and third Mondays of each month. All levels of play are welcome, and we are novice-friendly. Some people who come have never even held a ukulele, and if you contact Sandy ahead of time, she will bring an extra ukulele for you to try. Try it -- it's fun!

Music is usually selected from "The Daily Ukulele... 365 Songs for Better Living," by Liz and Jim Beloff. This book is readily available at music stores, book stores, and Amazon.com. Sometimes members bring other music to play (bring 15 copies to share). We play at a large conference table, so bring a table-top music stand if you have one.

Snacks and libations to share are welcome.

For more information, contact Sandy at [masked]

Directions to the Church: Take I279 North to Wexford exit. Turn right at the end of the exit. Right at the light onto Brandt School Road. Right onto West Ingomar Road to 2359. Note - watch for the large sign for the Church and then you will follow a narrow roadway back through the trees to the Church.

Depending on where you start, there may be a better route to the Church. Please check your GPS for different directions.
results.name: 3rd Monday in North Hills

results.description:
TypeScript is an open source, multi-paradigm language that compiles to JavaScript and is a superset of JavaScript. It is currently being developed by Microsoft and Google and will be the basis of Angular 2.

Format will be an about 45 minute presentation followed by an interactive live coding session combined with questions.

JavaScript knowledge is definitely helpful but not necessary. It will assume basic knowledge of modern language constructs  (classes, closures, lamdas, various forms of typing).

Matthew Beatty is Software Engineer at NetHealth. The project he is currently working on is written in TypeScript paired with Knockout on the frontend and Microsoft tech stack on the backend.
results.name: Intro to Type Script

results.description:
Join us on Tuesdays for American Mah Jong! Folks begin arriving around 5PM, and play begins table by table as soon as we have three or four players plus a set.  (We usually have 3-5 tables.)  By 6:15 or so, most players have arrived. We rotate among the tables... at the end of each game, East walks around to see if another table is close to the end of their game, so that two players can swap places.   At the other end of the evening... play must end by 9PM when Panera closes.  Tables begin wrapping up play any time after 8:15 or so.


If you have never played, or if you have not played for a very long time, we highly recommend that you take a Mah Jong 101 beginner class before playing with us - beginner classes are offered every few months.  Mah jong is a wonderful game, but it's hard to learn by just watching others play!


Please order your 2015 card from the National Mah Jongg League, here: http://www.nationalmahjonggleague.org/ Amazon.com also carries the cards. Note that you want the NMJL card, and no other! (There are some colorful alternatives out there.. but we play NMJL card and rules.)

Experienced players -- please bring your cards and please bring a set if you have one.

Please do not bring any outside food or beverages into Panera! Instead, please plan to buy *something* from Panera, even if it's just a beverage or a cookie, to support their willingness to host us.
results.how_to_find_us: Hard to miss us, look for the Mah Jong sets!

results.description:
Hello Book Lovers! For July, we chose Someday, Someday, Maybe by Lauren Graham (aka Lorelai and Sarah)

From Amazon.com:

From Lauren Graham, the beloved star of Gilmore Girls and Parenthood, comes a witty, charming, and hilariously relatable debut novel about a struggling young actress trying to get ahead―and keep it together―in New York City. It’s January 1995, and Franny Banks has just six months left of the three-year deadline she set for herself when she came to New York, dreaming of Broadway and doing “important” work. But all she has to show for her efforts so far is a part in an ad for ugly Christmas sweaters, and a gig waiting tables at a comedy club. Her roommates―her best friend Jane, and Dan, an aspiring sci-fi writer―are supportive, yet Franny knows a two-person fan club doesn’t exactly count as success. Everyone tells her she needs a backup plan, and though she can almost picture moving back home and settling down with her perfectly nice ex-boyfriend, she’s not ready to give up on her goal of having a career like her idols Diane Keaton and Meryl Streep. Not just yet. But while she dreams of filling their shoes, in the meantime, she’d happily settle for a speaking part in almost anything—and finding a hair product combination that works. Everything is riding on the upcoming showcase for her acting class, where she’ll finally have a chance to perform for people who could actually hire her. And she can’t let herself be distracted by James Franklin, a notorious flirt and the most successful actor in her class, even though he’s suddenly started paying attention. Meanwhile, her bank account is rapidly dwindling, her father wants her to come home, and her agent doesn’t return her calls. But for some reason, she keeps believing that she just might get what she came for. Someday, Someday, Maybe is a story about hopes and dreams, being young in a city, and wanting something deeply, madly, desperately. It’s about finding love, finding yourself, and perhaps most difficult of all in New York City, finding an acting job.


Please ask at the host stand for the book club. We are usually in the back room against the windows, but you never know...
results.why: We love to read, drink wine and talk about books!
results.how_to_find_us: Ask at the Host Stand for the Book Club

Regular season weekly street skate.

Come tour the east end of Pittsburgh on our Tuesday Advanced One Hour Fitness Skate. Helmet and wrist guards required at a minimum. Must know how to brake, do curbs, skate around potholes, negotiate hills, manuever in street traffic, etc. We return after about 1 hour skating Oakland, Highland Park, Squirrel Hill, Bloomfield and other venues that takes us 5 – 8 miles up and down hills and on flat roadway.

 

We skate on the streets, parks, and trails for a great workout.  See you there! Patrolled skate. Be ready to roll by 6:30 PM.

 Cyclists are welcome to join us! Bike with us to enjoy an evening tour of the city. Also if you have not skated this meetup, biking is a good way to check it out.

NOTE: All skates are "weather permitting".  If it is dry we should be skating.

results.description:
If you're into music, and even if you're not, here's a great opportunity to share any music you're interested in, have a cup of coffee or tea, and engage in conversation. We'll meet at Coffee Tree Roasters in Shadyside to chat, drink coffee, and listen to music. Bring your favorite music on your phone or thumb drive to share -- you can even bring an instrument to play if you'd like. And you can just come for the coffee and company – you absolutely aren't required to bring music (I will bring my laptop to look things up on YouTube as well).

Bring any music -- if you have music of your own creation, if you're passionate about a particular musician or band, or if you just like something and feel like sharing. It could be a recent find or something that influenced your childhood and got you though your teenage years. It could be something you love or it could even be something you hate -- just tell us why. Music is as much a story as anything -- it could be a story of you, or the story of the artist who created the music, or the story could be embedded in the song itself waiting for us to listen. Feel free to bring a story to share along with the music -- or not, if you prefer.

We're totally open to any kind of music so, please, bring anything you'd like to share be it classical, ethnic, heavy metal, or whatever -- even classical ethnic heavy metal (I bet it exists). We'll be meeting at Coffee Tree Roasters from 7pm (to probably 9pm though the room's booked until 10pm).

This event is also posted on meetin.org.
results.how_to_find_us: Inside Coffee Tree at 7pm, head to the glass-walled meeting room in the back.
results.name: Coffee Loves Music

Ever wonder about the voices in dubbed foreign films, animated movies, commercials and video games? They are done by voice actors, and you can learn about voice acting in this fun and informative seminar!  This is the same popular seminar that always sells out when offered in Washington DC, Austin and Atlanta. And now it is being offered again BY POPULAR DEMAND in Pittsburgh! 

NOTE: Voice Over is a growing field for those who are bi-lingual or multi-lingual; for teachers, actors, salespeople and all who use their voices in their professions.

Due to popular demand, there are only SIX HALF-PRICE ($12.50+) tickets available. Use this link to get all of the details and to purchase your half-price tickets:

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/pittsburgh-getting-paid-to-talk-an-introduction-to-voice-over-tickets-17480457519?discount=VCPittsburghAmazingHalfJuly21

TICKETS REQUIRED. EXACT LOCATION (in East End) WILL BE PROVIDED TO TICKET HOLDERS ONLY. Your RSVP to this meetup is not sufficient. This is a public event, not a meetup.

For more information about Voice Coaches, please visit http://voicecoaches.com/

So maybe you've been told you have a great voice, or perhaps people have suggested you should be in "radio." Maybe you use effective communication as part of your profession, or perhaps you're just interested in how people make money every day with their voices. From audio books and cartoons to documentaries, commercials and more, this class will introduce you to the growing field of voice-over. Today, the range of voices hired has grown dramatically and, unlike other fields, voice professionals are more in demand than ever before. Join us to learn what the pros look for, how to avoid common mistakes, and where to find work in your area! We’ll discuss industry pros and cons, play samples from working voice professionals and give you an opportunity to record a short script, under the direction of your instructor. This seminar is fun, realistic, and a great first step for anyone interested in the voice over field.

Getting Paid to Talk is a two-hour introduction to voice-overs, also known as voice acting. During the seminar, you'll learn:

What a voice-over is

What it is like on the job

Which voice types are most in demand

What a professional voice demo sounds like

Where to look for work opportunities

How to avoid common mistakes

Everyone in the class will have an opportunity to record a voice-over for in-class playback and instructor review.

Who should attend this seminar:

• Adults curious about or interested in the voice-over field

• Individuals who have been told they have a good voice

• People who use their voices prominently in their occupations

• People with music, theater, or creative backgrounds

Space is limited for this great introductory seminar on how to get paid to talk, so register today! FAQs

Are there ID requirements or an age limit to enter the event? Designed specifically for adults, though older children are welcome with parental accompaniment.

What are my transport/parking options getting to the event? Free parking on Station Street. There is also a city-run parking lot adjacent to the building, on Harvard Street and Sheridan Avenue with meter fees. DO NOT park in the Eastminster parking lot, Home Depot lot, or EECM staff lot. You will be towed from those lots.

Is my registration/ticket transferrable? Yes Can I update my registration information? No

Do I have to bring my printed ticket to the event? No What is the refund policy? If you are unable to attend, you will be given a credit for a future seminar.

The name on the registration/ticket doesn't match the attendee. Is that okay? Yes About Voice Coaches

Voice Coaches provides communication consulting, seminars, and professional audio production services to clients across the United States, Canada, and abroad.

With more than 20 years experience, our team has provided production services to clients including Discovery Network, HGTV, WE Network, TLC, CNN, Fox NY, and numerous other corporate, government, and private sector organiztions.

In addition, Voice Coaches provides consulting and professional demo development services to voice professionals.

We are members of two Chambers Of Commerce, The Voice and Speech Trainers Association, The American Society For Training and Development, and several other industry groups. We are also long-term members of The Better Business Bureau.

Our offices and studios are located at 26 Vly Road Albany NY 12205. We are available by phone[masked] X 100. Email [masked].

For more information about Voice Coaches, please visit http://voicecoaches.com/

results.description:
Marian L. Smith of the National Archives will present “How the Castle Garden Records Burned in the Ellis Island Fire” at the Genealogical Research Institute of Pittsburgh.  This evening lecture is free and open to the public.


Exactly what records burned in the 1897 fire that consumed Ellis Island? Were “some,” “many,” “most,” or “all” records destroyed? Were passenger lists destroyed or “only administrative” records? Some say State and municipal records were burned, but why would those records be at a Federal immigration station? Did we really lose anything in that fire? Join us for answers to these burning questions for New York passenger list research.
results.name: How the Castle Garden Records Burned in the Ellis Island Fire

results.description: Imagine living in a reality where you have no real pressure to get anything done ... where you never age ... where you have all of eternity to attack your bucket list ... well, guess what? You do! Nearly a century ago, Albert Einstein formulated that time does not exist (at least not independent of space) and so many of his brilliant colleagues have enhanced that concept such that it is now a foregone conclusion: we are timeless. In this group we will review the science of "eternity" and process spiritual applications of what it means that time is an illusion.

results.description:
Hi All,

We're meeting at 6:00 at the tennis court of Moon park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If a member is on the waiting list they can still come, however they may have to wait for courts to become available.
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,
results.name: Wednesday evening tennis - at Moon park

results.description:
Sparkle Dragon and I (Rebekah Gamble, Holistic Practitioner), are teaming up to bring you a class a month in 2015 in hopes of bringing helpful education and smiles to our community.

Our last tea class was SO MUCH FUN! that we're doing it again. We will briefly discuss the history and uses of tea, different brewing methods and what qualities these bring out of the tea, ethical and safe harvesting and preparation of herbal teas, and benefits of drinking tea. We will also have a number of herbal teas available for tasting and purchase if that suits your fancy.

The class will be at Sparkledragon's Magical Emporium on July 22nd at 6 pm with a one hour run time.

results.description: The "Incito Veritas" founding fathers (which included females, of course, as no soul has a gender) originally called this group "Fight Club" and first intended to keep that name while maintaining secrecy. So much for that. But the spirit of Fight Club remains, the idea of trying to bring out the best in each other through the evolution of consciousness. As Brad Pitt said about the movie, "Fight Club is a metaphor for the need to push through the walls we put around ourselves and just go for it." And not fear the pain! In this meetup we discuss ways that concepts introduced during the Incito Veritas series can be applied to our daily lives. We will learn and grow as we process our experiences. Bottom line: Knowing and Not Doing is Not Knowing, or as it says in James 2:26, "For as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without works is dead."

results.description:
Normally we meet on the 3rd Wednesday of each month but I will be away that day in July.  So we decided to meet on July 22nd instead.  

For July, we chose After the Rain by Karen White, which is the sequel to our May book, Falling Home.

Here's some info:

From “one of the best new writers on the scene today” (The Huffington Post) comes the sequel to Falling Home, a novel set in the picaresque town of Walton, Georgia, where one woman is about to discover that the best journey is the one that brings you home.… 

Freelance photographer Suzanne Paris has been on her own since she was fourteen—and she has no intention of settling down, especially not in a tiny town like Walton, Georgia. She’s here to hide out for a little while, not to form connections. Her survival depends on her ability to slip in and out of people’s lives, on never staying in one place for too long. 

But no one in Walton plans on making things easy for Suzanne. For one thing, it’s a town where everyone knows everyone else—and they all seem intent on making Suzanne feel right at home. For another, Suzanne can’t help but feel drawn to this tight-knit community—or to the town’s mayor, Joe Warner, and his six kids. But Suzanne can’t afford to stick around, even if she’s finally found a place where she belongs. Because someone is looking for her—someone who won’t stop until her life is destroyed…

results.description:
The Ashtavakra Gita is not as well known as some other Hindu scriptures. It is a very clear and direct pointing to non-duality in the form of a dialogue between a king and his guru. Little is known of its historical origins but it is greatly praised by many sages, including Ramana Maharshi. We will read some of the verses from it and discuss them. These two sites provide two different complete translations of this relatively brief work:
http://realization.org/p/ashtavakra-gita/richards.ashtavakra-gita/richards.ashtavakra-gita.html
http://www.holybooks.com/wp-content/uploads/Ashtavakra-Gita-ebook.pdf

This site provides a nice translation and commentary by Rajiv Kapur of the first chapter:

http://www.rajivkapur.com/writings.htm


 Copies of the verses to be read will be provided at the meeting.
results.name: Ashtavakra Gita

Hi All,

We're meeting at 7:30 at the tennis court of Schenley  park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If a member is on the waiting list they can still come, however they may have to wait for courts to become available.
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,

results.description:
I've been to this a couple of times it's fun... Frank the Admin


The Pittsburgh Banjo Club is a non-profit organization made up of men and women from all walks of life, with a common goal - the encouragement and preservation of the banjo, America’s Native Instrument. Founded on December 15, 1988, by Frank Rossi, the Pittsburgh Banjo Club is dedicated to keeping the music of the Golden Age of the Banjo alive [masked]). Frank Rossi was inducted into the National Four-String Banjo Hall of Fame on May 24, 2001. The Banjo Hall of Fame is located at the American Banjo Museum in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.

The Pittsburgh Banjo Club includes banjos, trumpets, tubas, and bass. Dressed in bright, colorful uniforms, the Pittsburgh Banjo Club makes a striking appearance while playing the happiest music in the world, putting a smile on your face, a tap in your toe and a song in your heart! The happiest sound in the world is a banjo and the Pittsburgh Banjo Club provides miles of smiles!

The Pittsburgh Banjo Club program consists of sing-alongs, vocals, banjo solos, music from the ’20s and ’30s, polkas and Dixieland.

results.description:
Let’s private-club hop in Oakland! The University Club rooftop terrace, with sweeping views of Oakland, is only open during select nights in the summer, and only to members. But we’re members and we’ve made arrangements to have you come as our guests before this opening performance of Figaro Redux!


We’re going to start at the U-Club around 5:30. Have bevs and bites (informal-buy as much or as little as you want) and walk over to the Twentieth Century Club two blocks away in plenty of time for the 7:30 pm curtain call.


About this progressive, shortened production of Marriage of Figaro:
Not so sure about opera? Love music from Figaro, but have problems sitting all evening? Then Figaro Redux is for you! In our slightly shorter, edgier modern-dress version of "The Marriage of Figaro" (by Mozart), you'll follow the cast around the building (nursing a cocktail, if you like!), with each act set in a different space in the spectacular Twentieth Century Club.


This one is all about sex and class: it was banned when first written, and later launched the French Revolution. And it is just as radical and subversive and entertaining today as it was back then.


More details on this production:
http://otsummerfest.org/events/figaro-redux

One other performance:
• Thursday 30 July at 7:30 pm


Want traditional Figaro? Still two more chances July 19 (7:30) and August 1 (2pm)


Trib review of July 11 Marriage of Figaro opening:


http://triblive.com/aande/music/8710170-74/figaro-mozart-production#axzz3fpAlVPdo


Pre-Curtain Talks

One hour before curtain time is an informal and informative talk with members of the Figaro Redux creative team. Free for all ticket holders—no reservations required.

• Thursday 23 July at 6:30 pm

• Thursday 30 July at 6:30 pm

Ticket Discounts:


Tickets are only $35 and are general admission.


If you are new to Opera Theater, you can receive up to three tickets at 33% off by calling the box office at[masked] or at the door. Students with ID can get rush tickets 50% off at door. http://otsummerfest.org/events/get-tickets

Other ticket discount options are also available. See the last section below for more detail.


More on Opera Theater SummerFest:

SummerFest 2015 is four weeks of opera sung in English, an international recital series, a children's opera, and more! Enjoy the world premiere of our newly-commissioned A New Kind of Fallout, two versions of Mozart's The Marriage of Figaro, Richard Strauss' enchanting Capriccio, and Damn Yankees, the all-American musical. Performances take place at the historic Twentieth Century Club in Oakland from July 10 – August 2. http://otsummerfest.org/events/calendar

For more information about the beautiful, historic Twentieth Century Club, please visit http://www.thetwentiethcenturyclub.com/index.html

Directions/Parking/Dining:
There is some street parking but most park across the street at Soldiers and Sailors.
http://otsummerfest.org/events/plan-your-visit

Other Ticket Discount Options

If anyone is interested in the Thursday, July 23 or Thursday, July 30 performance of "Figaro Redux", there are additional discount tickets of $22.50 (including ticket handling fees) offered through the Goldstar discount ticketing company http://www.goldstar.com/events/pittsburgh-pa/figaro-redux-tickets

FYI, here are other upcoming shows where Goldstar has access to discount tickets including other shows as part of the Opera Theater SummerFest http://www.goldstar.com/pittsburgh/events/?page=3&mode=infinite While Goldstar is not a substitute for more traditional savings/benefits through the usual subscriptions or other discount offers, it is a relatively new option for Pittsburgh. For more background/FAQ about Goldstar, including links to articles from the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, and Forbes, please visit http://www.goldstar.com/company Please note that Goldstar is free to join.

results.description:
PIZZA & SODAS WILL BE INCLUDED, so no worries about dinner for this one  :-)

We’ve all heard it before: “Content is King.” But why is content so important to the modern marketing methodology? How can content be leveraged to achieve goals and drive growth to a company’s website and the bottom line? In this workshop, we’ll go beyond blogging to discuss how to leverage several types of content to drive search traffic (SEO), establish thought leadership, drive new business and to cultivate a better relationship with customers than ever before. This workshop will feature hands-on exercises, which will result in  mini-content action plan for all participants.


As an inbound marketer and founder of Mixy Marketing, Meghan Skiff helps startups get more business. Destined to be a marketer, Meghan got her start when she won third place in her elementary school poster contest, using a celebrity endorsement to spread the word about the importance of fire safety. She then proceeded to spend her teenage years analyzing product positioning in Seventeen magazine while rocking out to Smashing Pumpkins. In her first official marketing job, Meghan learned how to use numbers to tell a story. She then moved on to explore roles in marketing communications and marketing management, where she utilized marketing strategy to build and execute successful campaigns and programs. As an early adopter of Inbound Marketing, Meghan shifted her focus toward leveraging content to create opportunities for small organizations to build brand and connect with customers. Meghan founded Mixy Marketing to help startups use the web to generate meaningful relationships with their customers

Limited to 30 attendees to ensure individualized attention
results.name: SEO & Content Marketing

results.description:
Every August at the Toastmasters International Convention, 81 competitors from all over the globe gather to compete in the World Championship of Public Speaking. It is our honor to host District 13's Champion, Michael Stanley, as he prepares for the competition by delivering his finals speech to the club. Michael will be competing in the semifinals with his award winning speech that we heard at our club's kick-off meeting on June 11th. If he wins that round, he will compete 2 days later in the finals with a completely different speech! Come hear Michael's speech that he hopes to present on the World Championship stage in Las Vegas in just a few short weeks. Give him your valuable feedback and help him bring the trophy home to Pittsburgh! 

About the Club:

There are over 50,000 residents living in Pittsburgh's Northside neighborhoods and until now there have been no open Toastmasters clubs for these communities. 

That changes with the establishment of the Northside Toastmasters to serve the community and develop its current and future leaders. In our meetings, members present prepared speeches, receive written and oral evaluations, practice impromptu speaking, and share fellowship in a supportive, non-intimidating environment. These experiences develop our members into greater communicators while practicing essential leadership skills. 

Toastmasters is a safe place to fail, to practice, to learn, and to grow into the best leader and communicator you can be. Come visit and find out what we can do for you! 

About Toastmasters

Current Toastmasters:

Please help us make this club a success and introduce this community to the incredible benefits Toastmasters has to offer. We need help spreading the word and ensuring that meetings run smoothly. If you are interested in volunteering to speak, fulfill a meeting role, or helping to promote the club; please let me know ASAP. If you are interested in sponsoring or mentoring this club (and earning credit toward your Advanced Leader Silver award in the process) please contact me directly. 


Thank you in advance for helping to bring the benefits of Toastmasters to the diverse and underserved communities of the Northside. Your involvement makes a difference!

Please note: The club will continue to meet at this location on the 2nd & 4th Thursday of each month from 6:30-7:30pm. Meetings are free and open to the public, all are welcome!

results.description:
Hello Ladies, I am delighted to announce the first read pick for our new book club, it is called "What Women Fear" by Angie Smith.  Thank you for the help in selection JoAnn,  Overview of the book is underneath the book picture. Remember, you need not have completed the entire book to attend, even if it is just a few chapters, pick what stood out, and share.  I will have two discussion questions to get us started.  I will have a date picked soon, just wanted to give you the title to start the book, it is also on Kindle.   Happy Reading!

Overview
“A true writer.” –Beth Moore

From a challenge of faith to a means of transformation

Did God really say you couldn’t eat from any tree in the garden? This seed of doubt planted so long ago still bears the fruit of fear on some level every day—the idea that our actions could ruin something beautiful and God might not have control over things.

In What Women Fear acclaimed writer and speaker Angie Smith admits, “Fear is a major part of my testimony” as she talks openly about significant struggles she has experienced. Giving a voice to the problem, she says, “I truly believe every single one of us struggles with some type of fear, whether it’s fear of flying or fear of being ‘found out.’ Maybe you don’t worry about dying, but you get sick thinking about the fact that you might fail.”

Instead of suggesting that those who love the Lord would never fear, Angie blends her own experiences with those of men and women throughout Scripture to help us start dealing more effectively with these true, human emotions.

Whether it’s a constant What if? type of worry, being afraid of abandonment or betrayal, fear of trusting God’s plan, or many others encountered in the rhythm of our daily lives, Angie walks you through stories of others who have simultaneously loved God and struggled with faith. Journey with her as she explores the difficult and life-giving questions God asked of those who walked a similar road. Discover how to redeem this struggle as only God can—that He will be glorified, and you will be transformed.

Angie Smith is the wife of Todd Smith (lead singer of Dove Award winning group Selah), author of I Will Carry You, and a national women’s conference speaker. She holds a Master’s degree in Developmental Psychology from Vanderbilt University and lives with her husband and daughters in Nashville, Tennessee.

results.description:
Don't miss this opportunity to learn from an expert all the first-aid supplies you'll need for your next outdoor adventure. We'll start by focusing on the five basic variables to consider when building a first-aid kit: group size, trip length and distance, potential injuries and illnesses, specific medical conditions and your own medical knowledge and skills. Plus, we'll discuss the benefits of assemble-it-yourself first-aid kits vs. pre-assembled kits. You'll also participate in a hands-on, small-group discussion of the contents needed for a first-aid kit based on three different outing scenarios. You'll assess the needs of each kit based on the first three basic variables outlined earlier in the clinic. Afterwards, the whole group will come together to discuss what first-aid materials would be needed for each scenario. Our experts will also briefly explain the purpose for each item in the kit. They also discuss where it should be placed, so it can be quickly located during stressful emergency situations. Please note: This is not a first-aid certification class. Proper first-aid training is very important for knowing what to do in emergency situations. You should only attempt first aid when you feel comfortable giving it.


Thank you for your interest in our free "First Aid Kits Clinic." L.L.Bean has a new centralized reservation system. To guarantee your space, you must first confirm your reservation on our new centralized reservation system, and if appropriate, fill out a participant agreement. Please visit www.llbean.com/pittsburgh, find this event on the "Event Calendar", and register. We look forward to seeing you!

results.description:
Join The Rage of the Stage Players for a night filled with dark, edgy, original theatre as they tell the story of Alice in Wonderland like you have never seen it before. Alice's Adventures in Wonderland features familiar characters from Lewis Carroll's novel...with a twist. 

SYNOPSIS:

Alice, an innocent Catholic schoolgirl, is lured away from a field trip by a mischievous punk, the "White" Rabbit. She pursues him and finds herself in “Wonderland,” a seedy area of the city populated by a host of re-imagined, real-world counterparts to Carroll's beloved characters. Favorites such as the Caterpillar, the Cheshire Cat, and the Queen of Hearts appear in Alice’s world, but not as audiences may expect—instead, we find a victim of Alzheimer's Disease, a drug addict with a smile that just won't quit, and a dominatrix with her own bondage club.


Mature content, not advisable for younger audience members.

Come follow us down the rabbit hole July 23, 24, & 25 at 8:00 PM at Mckeesport Little Theater.

Tickets $15.00 (Cash at the door) -- But Please Call for reservations (724)[masked] as these performances may sell out.

To learn more about The Rage of Stage Players, please visit http://rageofthestage.com/

Check out this great review of the show http://www.pghstage.com/drupal_old/node/606

For more information about this Production

Celebrating the 150th anniversary of Lewis Carroll's beloved book of the same name, The Rage of the Stage Players proudly announce the Pittsburgh return of their gritty, urban stage production, Alice's Adventures in “Wonderland,”

Pittsburgh playwright James Michael Shoberg brings us a darker, modernized interpretation of Lewis Carroll's story about young Alice Liddell, "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" (1865). Although Shoberg's version is an edgier, more twisted adaptation of the story, Carroll's plot and poems remain intact. Fans of Carroll’s work will appreciate the numerous subtle references to characters and songs, as well as other hidden—and not-so-hidden—gems.

Having been produced from coast-to-coast and internationally, this marks the third time the play will be seen in Pittsburgh.

Previous Productions include:

The Rage of the Stage Players - Pittsburgh, PA (September 2006)

The Rage of the Stage Players - Pittsburgh, PA (May 2009)

Paper Wing Theatre Company - Monterey, CA (April 2010)

Adam Roebuck Studios - New York, NY (October 2011)

Scorpio Theatre - Calgary, Canada (February 2012)

Unquiet Theatre Company - Lorton, Virginia (February 2015)

The Cuckoo’s Theater Project - Chicago, Illinois (March 2015)

“Alice’s Adventures in ‘Wonderland’ is tailor made for the young, hip, adventurous wing of the Pittsburgh theater crowd.” -- John Hayes, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette


To learn more about The Rage of the Stage Players, please visit http://rageofthestage.com/

For more information about McKeesport Little Theater, please visit http://www.mckeesportlittletheater.com/


MEETUP Considerations

When you RSVP, please consider posting comments below to indicate which performance date you prefer:

    Thursday, July 23 at 8 PM


    Friday, July 24 at 8 PM


    Saturday, July 25 at 8 PM


As always, it is also fine if you wish to attend the show on your own with family/friends instead.

results.description:
We will be tent camping 5 dollars per person per night. Sat at 10AM Outback Adventures will shuttle us up to Tidioute for a 15 mile paddle down the Allegheny. It will be at least 5 hrs. With lunch and fishing and swimming will take the good part of the day. A few rapids nothing over class one. The river is a constant 3-4ft deep. We can have a leisurely paddle enjoying the sun and water, and float into our campground so no rush to get off the water. Everyone is responsible for their own food and drink for the weekend. There is a Subway in town that I have found convenient for packing lunch and snacks for Sat. Everyone should bring water shoes,sunscreen and a watertight bag for their phone or camera. A PFD if bringing their own kayak. The price for shuttling your own kayak is 19 dollars. The rental price is 38 dollars. We can then camp out Sat night again 5 dollars per person and leave Sun morning. I will have to make reservations ahead of time. Hoping for some bright sunny weather!

* This meetup is cross posted on PALS*
results.how_to_find_us: On rt 62, 40 yards south of the Tionesta Bridge

results.description:
What Bible verses do you commonly hear misused and abused when you talk to people about God and His word? Bring a list of some of your favorites to this discussion. Here are 5-6 that we will plan on talking about outside of what you bring:

•  “Judge not, that you be not judged" (Matthew 7:1). 

•  "For where two or three are gathered in my name, there am I among them” (Matthew 18:20). 

• "And we know that God causes all things to work together for good..." (Romans 8:28). 

• "I can do all things through Him who strengthens me" (Philippians 4:13).

• "For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life" (John 3:16). 

• "For I know the plans I have for you, declares the LORD, plans for welfare and not for evil, to give you a future and a hope" (Jeremiah 29:11). 

• "Behold, I stand at the door and knock; if anyone hears My voice and opens the door, I will come in to him and will dine with him, and he with Me" (Revelation 3:20).
results.how_to_find_us: If you do not see me, text or call me 412-999-4837
results.name: Ripped Out of Context: The Most Misused Bible Verses

results.description:
A WHOLE NEW CONCERT EXPERIENCE ... Theatre of Music

The Pittsburgh New Music Ensemble (PNME) offers some of the most innovative performances during summer weekends at City Theater in the South Side.  These acclaimed performances often include world premieres of new works showcasing contemporary music, dance movements, theatre, and cutting-edge video artistry.

The PNME involves unique collaborations among musicians, artists, and composers from Pittsburgh and throughout North America. Since its founding in 1976, PNME has commissioned and premiered over 200 works. 

The 2015 PNME Season begins the weekend of July 10-11, and continues for four weekends until July 31 - August 1.

﻿To check out the entire PNME 40th Anniversary season, please visit http://www.pnme.org/season/

Check out this great preview article about PNME's upcoming concerts this summer http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/music/2015/07/07/Preview-PNME-celebrates-40-years-of-charting-new-music-territory/stories/201507070057

Each PNME concert is unique. But to check out an example video of what these PNME concerts may be like, please visit http://www.pnme.org/videos/ or http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KrJgpZm8t00

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KrJgpZm8t00


PNME is also excited to start a new "BYO Bottle of Wine" tradition this season! Bring whatever you wish and we can cork it after the performances, while you hang with the artists and fellow audience members! Each show, a different artist or board member will prepare a food delicacy to share with you. Experience the show, then let us get to know you better over a glass of wine and some nibbles! http://www.pnme.org/news-events/

Concert #3 (July 24-25) "RETURN FLIGHT"

The long awaited return of PNME's signature Return Flight production! Based on the incredible "Musica Ricercata" of György Ligeti, Return Flight is a spiral forward and backward blending music, poetry, clapping, and scrabble into an inescapable and inevitable corkscrew. Works by composers Thierry de Mey and Amy Williams, as well as poets William Langford and Danny Spiegel are only a few of the delights along the way.

For more information about the remarkable poet William Langford, please visit http://www.willthepoet.com/ William Langford is from Detroit and will be performing alongside the PNME musicians for this very special and inspiring evening which takes place on both Friday July 24 and Saturday July 25.

These PNME Concerts are typically 1-2 hours, so it is not too long of an evening -- and is easily incorporated with other plans, such as dining before the show or going out for a drink afterwards.

In addition, if you have never been to a PNME concert before, PNME graciously offers first timers a free ticket!! First timers can pick up their free ticket at the Box Office beginning at 7 PM (one hour before the concert). See below for details.

Also, as another discount bonus -- if you've been to PNME before and bring someone new, you'll pay just $15 ticket.

And if you bring two first timers, then you go for free!

MEETUP Considerations

When you RSVP, please indicate which performance date you prefer (Friday July 24 or Saturday July 25)

TICKETS (If you're not a first timer, and need to buy tickets)

Please visit http://www.pnme.org/tickets or call ShowClix 1.888.71.TICKETS [masked])

Season Package: save up to 40% with 4 tickets for $80 (or $40 students/seniors) Must be ordered in advance. Applies to weekend concerts only - 4 tickets total. Choose Friday nights or Saturday nights. Easy ticket replacement, exchange, and donation options.

Single Tickets:

◦General Admission: $25 advance

◦Students: $10 advance

*Seniors: $15 advance, $17.50 at door

Student discount applies to ages 26 & younger, or those with a full-time student ID; Senior discount applies to ages 62 & older. Limit one ticket per I.D.

•First Limers*: FREE! – only available at door beginning at 7 PM

*A first limer is a first time attendee.

*And if you bring a first timer, then you pay only $15 at the door!

*And if you bring two first timers, then you go for free!

For more information, please visit the PNME Homepage with links to videos, music, and reviews http://pnme.org

results.description:
Are you ready to ride?

You’re invited to join our Saturday morning, beginners group ride starting from and ending at our Pittsburgh, Performance Bicycle store. The ride is for beginners and those getting back on the saddle. The average pace will be between 10 and 14 miles per hour and the ride will last approximately one hour. The ride leaves the store every Saturday morning, 9:00 am and is a “No Rider Left Behind” ride. Come out and join our ride leaders, for some fun outdoors.

Bring a helmet, waterbottle, spare tube, positive attitude :)

results.description:
This workout will consist of barbell movements and running in the following sequence:

Run 1 lap
10 power clean and jerks
Run 1 lap
10 power clean and jerks
Run 1 lap
10 power clean and jerks
Run 1 lap 
10 power clean and jerks
Run 1 lap
10 power clean and jerks
Run 1 lap

The total work done is 6 laps of running (~1.5 miles) and 50 power clean and jerks.  Athletes new to the barbell lifts will do the power cleans from the "hang" (between the knees and waste).

We will begin this workout as a group and four different barbells (25lb - 145lb) will accommodate various strength levels.  It is not a race.  The goal is to complete the sequence and encourage your fellow athletes to do the same.  The workout will build your work capacity and help you become more efficient and proficient with the barbell movements. We will keep time so that you can have a personal benchmark on the workout and make improvements.

The videos hyperlinked below illustrate the basic barbell movements.  If you are new to these, then plan to arrive at 9:00 am.  I will teach/review technique from 9:00-9:30.  If you are familiar with these movements, then you can plan to arrive at 9:20.  At least 10 minutes of warm-up is recommended for all athletes.  Group workout will begin at 9:35.

Visitors Always Welcome!

The Pittsburgh Model Club (East) is sponsored by the Pittsburgh Chapter of BetterInvesting for the purpose of teaching investment club operations and investment decision-making techniques.  This Model Club focuses on using computerized techniques to screen for potential investments, to analyze stocks of interest, and to manage a stock portfolio.

Anyoyne can attend as a visitor and is eligible to apply for a membership. Visitors are encouraged to participate in our lively discussions (but only members my vote on investment decisions for the club)

Each member invests between $10 and $100 per month and the club maintains an investment portfolio following BetterInvesting procedures.

Prerequisite: A desire to learn about investing or, if you are already an active investor, a desire to improve your investing decisions.

results.description:
The previous May 16 date needed to be rescheduled due to travel plans.

Saturdays in June were completely booked at the Museum, so the new date is Saturday, July 25.


We will have a  tour of the World War I collection at Soldiers & Sailors Memorial Hall & Museum.  Our tour guide is Tim Neff, Director of Education & Curatorial Services.  Tim will show us the regular WWI collection, and will also let us see some items from their archives.

The cost of the tour is $7.00 per person.


Enter the lobby of the Museum from the main entrance on Fifth Avenue.

We'll meet at 9:45 am to pay our admission and get assembled.

The tour runs from 10:00 to 11:30 am.

At the conclusion of the tour, we'll head to the Porch Restaurant in nearby Schenley Plaza for brunch.  Staying to eat is optional, but it will be a good opportunity to discuss what we've seen, and any other WWI news we want to share.


Parking is available at the Soldiers & Sailors garage.  On-street parking is also available.


=======================================================


Click HERE for more information about Soldiers & Sailors Memorial Hall & Museum.


For more information about the parking garage near Soldiers & Sailors, click HERE.


Check out the MENU and PRICES for The Porch at Schenley.


RSVPs accepted through end of the day Thursday, July 23.

Guests are welcome.  Just indicate "+1" etc in your RSVP.

Looking forward to seeing group members from prior meetings, and some new faces, too.

Jeannine

======================================================


FRIDAY, JULY 24 UPDATE

Here's the day-before update for our museum tour.

All info above is the the same as originally posted.

Some additional info/clarifications:

S&S prefers cash for the admission, but can take cards if you prefer to pay that way.

S&S is not directly across from the Cathedral of Learning, but on a diagonal.  Click on the S&S link above for the map.

Parking should probably be plentiful on a Saturday morning during summer, but it's still Oakland.  Please give yourself enough time to park.  The charges at parking kiosks vary, but there will almost certainly be a charge to park in a kiosk zone.  You can pay with cash or cards.

The Porch Restaurant is a few minutes walk from S&S.  See the map below for the specific location:

http://tinyurl.com/pbzwt2c

We have 8-10 people signed up for this, which is the minimum number that S&S requested.

If you cannot attend, please PM me or indicate in the comments below

Likewise, IF YOU WANT TO ATTEND AND MISSED THE RSVP CUTOFF, PM ME OR POST IN THE COMMENTS.  We can easily add more people.

My cell phone is[masked]-6848.

I will be checking this page and my phone periodically until shortly after the tour starts.

Looking forward to seeing everyone!

Jeannine

results.description:
Lights! Camera! Pittsburgh! is the Official Pittsburgh Film Office Movie Tour!


Calling all movie buffs! Celebrate the "Hollywood of the East" where movies and film crews abound! Join your knowledgeable guide as we travel around the city exploring great sites featured in some of Hollywood's blockbusters! Enjoy an interactive tour through the city backdrops of such movies as "The Dark Knight Rises", "The Perks of Being a Wallflower", "Promised Land", "Flashdance", "The Next Three Days", "Inspector Gadget", "Love & Other Drugs", "Abduction", "Jack Reacher" and dozens more! Treats included! Spend part of your day learning about Pittsburgh's unique and rich film history. Meet at the upper deck of the Duquesne Incline. Parking is available in the lower station lot near 1197 W Carson St Pittsburgh, Pa 15219. This tour includes a free ride up the historic incline! Let the cashier at the lower deck know that you are part of the movie tour.

This tour will last approximately 2.5 hours.
The cost is $49.25 per ticket. Go to
http://www.showclix.com/event/Movietour25 to
buy your ticket. Do not show up without a ticket, as
this tour does sell out. Took it last year, lots of fun! You will be shocked at what a movie history Pittsburgh has.
results.name: PITTSBURGH MOVIE TOUR

results.description:
Preserving Your Italian Heritage
Saturday, July 25, 2015 • 10:00 am - 12:00 pm

Join us for a program on preserving your Italian heritage through family heirlooms and documents. Enjoy a tour of the Italian American collection at the History Center and a behind-the-scenes tour of the Sigo Falk Collections Center. Learn how to best handle and store paper, textiles, and 3-D objects.
This program is a collaborative presentation with Melissa Marinaro, curator of the Italian American Program, and Barb Antel, conservation services manager at the Museum Conservation Center.

Registration

Pre-registration is required. Please contact Barb Antel at[masked] or [masked] to reserve your place in the workshop.

This workshop costs $30 for History Center members and $35 for non-members. One free admission to the Heinz History Center is included.

Workshop kits can be ordered in advance at $20 per kit (optional).
results.name: PRESERVE YOUR ITALIAN HERITAGE (Heinz History Center)

results.description:
Please join us for a wonderful family performance of "The True Story of the Three Little Pigs"  - the first performance will be held on Saturday, July 11 at 11:00 am at the Beaux Arts Ballroom in the Twentieth Century Club in Oakland. And then this show will be repeated every Saturday morning (July 11, 18, 25 and August 1) during the Opera Theater SummerFest.


Immerse the whole family in this delightful take on a classic story!  So, did the wolf just get a bad rap? This musical adventure is an attention-friendly 40 minute fun show and a great introduction to opera for children of all ages.  Kids get to sit within a few feet of the singers in the intimate Beaux Arts Ballroom for this up-close and casual performance.


Please see the Opera Theater SummerFest website for details on special pre-show guests, like composer Wallace DePue, and plan to enjoy piggy-themed activities and crafts after the show. Free lemonade and popcorn, fun (including photo opps with singers/characters and others), and surprises abound!  Directed by Dennis Robinson, Jr.


Performances:
• Saturday 11 July at 11:00 am
• Saturday 18 July at 11:00 am
• Saturday 25 July at 11:00 am
• Saturday 01 August at 11:00 am 

This show is performed in under an hour (with no intermission) and so there would be plenty of time for friends/family to enjoy the rest of their Saturday. And there are many great places people could check out with a just few minutes walk, such as the Carnegie Museums, Schenley Plaza, Soldiers & Sailors Museum, Phipps Conservatory, Carnegie Library (where there are free activities during weekend afternoons), Cathedral of Learning Nationality Rooms, etc. as well as many restaurants in Oakland.

As always, it is also fine if you wish to enjoy this performance on your own with family and friends instead.


Tickets:
Adults: $10
Children: $5 

Groups of 8 or more save 10%
Groups of 20 or more save 20% 

Other ticket discount options are also available. See the last section below for more detail.


For more information and to buy tickets:
http://otsummerfest.org/events/the-three-pigs 


More on Opera Theater SummerFest:
SummerFest 2015 is four weeks of opera and musicals sung in English, an international recital series, a children's opera, cabarets and more! Enjoy the world premiere of our newly-commissioned A New Kind of Fallout, two versions of Mozart's The Marriage of Figaro, Richard Strauss' enchanting Capriccio, and Damn Yankees, the all-American musical. Performances take place at the historic Twentieth Century Club in Oakland from July 10 – August 2. http://otsummerfest.org/events/calendar 

Check out these great articles about the Opera Theater SummerFest and the various shows during July 10 – August 2 http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/music/2015/07/09/Opera-Theater-s-SummerFest-offers-unusual-productions-to-attract-new-audiences/stories/201507090084

http://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/opera-theaters-summerfest-features-rachel-carson-inspired-work/Content?oid=1838370

http://triblive.com/aande/music/8737351-74/alice-opera-act#axzz3gUTWiClg

http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/music/2015/07/19/Opera-Theater-of-Pittsburgh-draws-powerful-connections-inspired-by-Rachel-Carson-s-book/stories/201507190203

http://triblive.com/aande/music/8737321-74/capriccio-strauss-opera#axzz3gmWdREZG

We've also added a Discussion Board forum for those that may wish to suggest some shows where perhaps some smaller groups of people could get together depending on their schedules. Please visit http://www.meetup.com/Art-lovers/messages/boards/thread/49092583

For more information about the beautiful, historic Twentieth Century Club, please visit http://www.thetwentiethcenturyclub.com/index.html


Directions/Parking/Dining:

There is some street parking but most park across the street at Soldiers and Sailors. Detailed directions and dining options: http://otsummerfest.org/events/plan-your-visit

Other Ticket Discount Options

If anyone is interested in the Saturday, July 18 or Saturday, July 25 morning performances, there are additional discount tickets of $2.50 children and $7.50 adults (including ticket handling fees) offered through the Goldstar discount ticketing company http://www.goldstar.com/events/pittsburgh-pa/the-true-story-of-the-3-little-pigs-tickets

FYI, here are other upcoming shows where Goldstar has access to discount tickets including other shows as part of the Opera Theater SummerFest http://www.goldstar.com/pittsburgh/events/?page=3&mode=infinite While Goldstar is not a substitute for more traditional savings/benefits through the usual subscriptions or other discount offers, it is a relatively new option for Pittsburgh. For more background/FAQ about Goldstar, including links to articles from the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, and Forbes, please visit http://www.goldstar.com/company Please note that Goldstar is free to join.

results.description:
The Topic


Welcome to the 12th meeting of the Pittsburgh Apologetics Club. The topic for this meeting is, "Calvinism and Free Will and The Problem of Evil".


We will be continuing our discussion from last time about free will, specifically about the beliefs of Calvinists and other Christian denominations. If you remember we did not get a chance to discuss this last time because we ran out of time.


We will also be discussing The Problem of Evil. This is somewhat related to the free will topic. Did God create evil? Is evil necessary for good to exist? What is evil? What is good? Is there such a thing as objective good and objective evil? Can we be good without God? And other questions along the same lines.


What will we do

As usual, we will watch a few videos related to the topics, and then go around the table and discuss the videos and topics in general as a group. As was suggested in the previous meeting, we will watch a video, discuss it, then watch another video, discuss it, and so on.

Important: Please follow the rules on this website during the meeting

http://ukranians2.wix.com/pgh-apologetics-club#!meetup-group/cwzz

We had some problems during the last meeting because people failed to follow the rules. People got offended. Remember, these are challenging topics. Why don't you discuss religion and politics at the dinner table? Because it causes WW3 among your family members. This is a club where we discuss those topics and try to be civil about it. 

People have different opinions, and the only way we will get anywhere is if we respect each other and give each other a fair hearing, and DO NOT talk over someone else while they are speaking.
results.how_to_find_us: Meeting Room C
results.name: Apologetics Club Meeting 12

results.description:
Could Troy Hill be the most diverse urban landscape in Pittsburgh? It's got an island, a leafy riverfront trail, a major highway, steep hills, historic homes, modern lofts, a plateau with breathtaking views, and much more! We won't walk past all of it, but we'll cover some of it and take you to great vantage points to see the rest on an urban hike of Troy Hill!


We'll begin at the parking lot under the 31st Street Bridge on Washington's Landing (yep, that's part of Troy Hill) and end around 2:00pm at Scratch food & beverage, a restaurant coming to Troy Hill in August, but holding a special event the evening of the hike and opening early just for us! In between, we'll take in the murals along the new Route 28 walkway, visit a unique bookstore and gallery space, climb some city steps... we could go on, but we'd rather save it for the hike!


So, join us on Saturday, July 25th and bring some scratch for Scratch (they're still cash only at this point). Other necessary items? A water bottle, comfortable shoes, and whatever the day's weather requires - we hike rain or shine!


We look forward to seeing you Saturday!


(Never heard of Urban Hike before this announcement? We’re a casual, all-volunteer group that explores the neighborhoods and boroughs around Pittsburgh on foot, and invites others to join us. Learn more at www.urbanhike.com.)
results.how_to_find_us: You'll see a group of people standing by the entrance to the parking lot
results.name: Urban Hike in Troy Hill
